Ensure that the use of applications and platforms does not violate students’ data privacy.
Waɗugo yo'o huwidol be applikasionji be daldalji memmata amana matinolji jaangowo.
Prioritize solutions to address psychosocial challenges before teaching: Mobilize available tools to connect schools, parents, teachers, and students with each other.
Hokkugo mangu ha dabareji nattinugo larulaji hakkilo: moftugo kujeji je ɗon wondi ngam jokkugo jaangirdeji, baabiraɓe, jaanginoɓe, be jaangoɓe oya be oya.
Create communities to ensure regular human interactions, enable social caring measures, and address possible psychosocial challenges that students may face when they are isolated.
Wurtinugo ummatoji ngam wanginugo dabareji feere-feere ha kunde yimɓe, waɗugo dabareji suklugo do ummatore, e willugo saɗirmaji feere je footi memma hakkilo jaangoɓe to ɓe ɗon joɗɗi feere maɓɓe.

Plan the study schedule of the distance learning programmes: Organise discussions with stakeholders to examine the possible duration of school closures and decide whether the distance learning programme should focus on teaching new knowledge or enhance students’ knowledge of prior lessons.

Waɗugo jaahargalji ngam dabareji ekkitol nayinde: ngewta be mawɓe ngam lartugo neeɓol maɓɓolji jaangirde je footi waɗa be hasdugo to jaahargal ekkitol dayinde wondan do jaanginugo kujeji keese mala lartugo ko ɓe jaangi timmi ha nder suudu jaangirde.
Plan the schedule depending on the situation of the affected zones, level of studies, needs of students needs, and availability of parents.
Waɗugo jaahargal do jonde wakkere nde, ta'irde jaangirdeji, haajeji jaangoɓe, be wondugo baabiraɓe.
Choose the appropriate learning methodologies based on the status of school closures and home-based quarantines.
Suɓɓugo dabareji jaangirdeji kanduɗum do maɓɓolji jaangirde e do wondugo ha seera ha saare bo'o.
Avoid learning methodologies that require face-to-face communication.
Luttugo dabareji ekkitol je ɗon emma ngewte je gite nder gite.
Provide support to teachers and parents on the use of digital tools: Organise brief training or orientation sessions for teachers and parents as well, if monitoring and facilitation are needed.
Hokkugo wallende ha jaanginoɓe ba baabiraɓe do kujeji kugal be internati: taskugo geeɓeji ekkitol mala feelore ngam jaanginoɓe be baabiraɓe fu, to aynol be wallende naffan.
Help teachers to prepare the basic settings such as solutions to the use of internet data if they are required to provide live streaming of lessons.
Wallugo jaangoɓe taskugo wakkere aranool bana dabareji huwugo be internati to ɓe emmotto waɗugo jaangirde gal wondugo ha yeeso jaangoɓe nder ordo.

Blend appropriate approaches and limit the number of applications and platforms: Blend tools or media that are available for most students, both for synchronous communication and lessons, and for asynchronous learning.

Hawtugo dabareji kanduɗum e darna limgal applikasionji e daaldal: Hawtugo kujeji mala dabareji je ɗon ngondi ha ɓurna jaangoɓe fu, ɗiɗi fu ngam ha ngewte be ekkitolji yahida boɗɗum, be jaangirde je ɗon feere.
Avoid overloading students and parents by asking them to download and test too many applications or platforms.
Accugo hebbinugo applikasionji mala daaldal ha jaangoɓe be baabiraɓe gal emmugo ɓe hoosugo e waɗɗugo kujeji jur.
Develop distance learning rules and monitor students’ learning process: Define the rules with parents and students on distance learning.
Wurtinugo tawretaji jaangirde dayindi be fadugo laahal jaangirde jaangowo: sappinugo tawretaji do jaangirde dayinki ha baabiraɓe be jaangoɓe.
Design formative questions, tests, or exercises to monitor closely students’ learning process.
Dida emmolji, lartolji, kuɗe ekkitol ngam fadugo laahal ekkitol jaangoɓe.
Try to use tools to support submission of students’ feedback and avoid overloading parents by requesting them to scan and send students’ feedback
Foondugo huwugo be kujeji ngam wallugo jaangowo ngewta be moɗon e accugo emmugo baabiraɓe gal emmugo ɓe ngam hoosa foto e nelda ngewte jaangoɓe be hoore maɓɓe.

Define the duration of distance learning units based on students’ self-regulation skills: Keep a coherent timing according to the level of the students’ self-regulation and metacognitive abilities especially for livestreaming classes.

Hokkugo wakati ekkitol dayindi do dabare wondugo aandalji jaangoɓe: Wurtinugo jaahargal je ɗon yahida be yaɓɓorde jaangirde be dabareji aandal feere-feere ɓurna fu je jaangirdeji je gite be gite do ordo.
Preferably, the unit for primary school students should not be more than 20 minutes, and no longer than 40 minutes for secondary school students.
Ndikka yo'o, ekkitol jaangoɓe jaangirde aranool ta ɓura minti 20, e ta ɓura minti 40 je jaangoɓe jaangirde ɗiɗaɓool.

Create communities and enhance connection: Create communities of teachers, parents, and school managers to address sense of loneliness or helplessness, facilitate sharing of experience and discussion on coping strategies when facing learning difficulties.

Wurtinugo ummatoreji e haɓda ngam ngidol: wanginugo ummatoreji jaanginoɓe, baabiraɓe, be arduɓe jaangirde ngam tato ɓe wona feere maɓɓe mala bila wallende, latina saanjol aandal be ngewte kooyɗum do dabareji wurtol to wodi saɗirmaji nder ekkitol.
290 million students out of school due to COVID-19: UNESCO releases first global numbers and mobilizes response, UNESCO.
Jaangoɓe milionji 290 ha yaasi jaangirde ngam COVID-19: UNESCO wurtini aranool limgal duniyaru e hawti jabbuye, UNESCO.
Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19
Aynolji sababu ha wakkere kugal ngam COVID-19
Workplace hazard controls for COVID-19 are the application of occupational safety and health methodologies for hazard controls to the prevention of coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
Aynolji sababu ha wakkere kugal ngam COVID-19 lati dabareji huwidugo do wakkere e jam ɓaandu ngam aynolji nyau koronaviriis 2019 (COVID-19).

The proper hazard controls in the workplace depend on the worksite and job task, based on a risk assessment of sources of exposure, disease severity in the community, and risk factors of individual workers who may be vulnerable to contracting COVID-19.
Aynolji sababu ha wakkere kugal ɗon saanja be wakkere kugal be irin kugal man, do lartol sababu wondugo, nyaɗugo nyau ha nder ummatore, be kujeji je footi saɗɗina huwooɓe je footi raɓɓa COVID-19.

According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers, for which basic infection prevention measures are recommended, including hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.

U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) wi'i yo'o, irin kuɗe petpetel maray sababuji jur ngam hoosatta baabe jur be ummatore mala be huwooɓe feere, je dabareji aynol nyau aranool feelama, bana lallugo juɗe, sembintinugo huwooɓe joɗɗa ha saare to ɓe nyauɗo, laɓɓinugo lawol pofɗe, be laɓɓugo e laɓɓinugo baabe kugal.

Medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact with people who are not known or suspected with COVID-19, but may be infected due to ongoing community transmission or international travel.

Kuɗe je sababu naangugo nyau deydey larni ɓe'en je ɗon ngida be je on aanda mala bana ɗon roondi nyau COVID-19, amma je footi raɓɓa nyau ndu ngam sallinol ummatore je jonta mala gal jaahangal ha lesdi feere.
This includes workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.
Ndu larni huwoɓe je mari dabare footugo be ummatore bana ha jaangirde, wakkere kugal je yimɓe ɗon jur, wakkeriji je kujeji sippitol jur ɗon mofti ha ton.

Hazard controls for this group, in addition to basic infection prevention measures, include ventilation using high-efficiency air filters, sneeze guards, and having personal protective equipment available in case a person with COVID-19 is encountered.

Aynolji sababu geeɓe ndu, ha ɓesdugo ha dabareji aynol nyau je aranool, wodi hendu gal ordoji je ɗon haɗɗa gilɗiji salla, leepol je suddata ɓislol, be marugo limse fadol hoore mum je ɗon woni to on ɗon ngida be goɗɗo je ɗon mari COVID-19.

OSHA considers healthcare and mortuary workers exposed to known or suspected person with COVID-19 to be at high exposure risk, which increases to very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected person with COVID-19.

OSHA ɗon limma huwooɓe do jam ɓaandu be huwooɓe do mayɓe bana hoore maɓɓe ɗon sappini mala goɗɗo je footi mara COVID-19 lati bana mari sababu maungel, ko ɗon ɓesdina ha sababu je tuuli to huwooɓe ɗon ngaɗa laahalji je ɗon wurtina aerosol do, malla ɗon mofta, mala ɗon memma lekkuji, goɗɗo je ɗon mari mala je footi mara COVID-19.
Hazard controls appropriate for these workers include engineering controls such as negative pressure ventilation rooms, and personal protective equipment appropriate to the job task.
Aynolji sababu je kanduɗum ngam irin huwooɓe ngu larni aynolji injiiniya'en bana cuuɗi je hendu ɗo boɗɗe, be kujeji sudol je ɗon yahida be kugal ngel.
COVID-19 outbreaks can have several effects within the workplace.
Nyauji COVID-19 footi mara sababuji jur ha nder wakkere kugal.
Workers may be absent from work due to becoming sick, needing to care for others, or from fear of possible exposure.
Huwooɓe footi wondatta ha kugal ngam ɓe raɓɓi nyau, ngam ɓe yiɗi suklugo do yimɓe feere, mala ngam hulol naangugo nyau.
Patterns of commerce may change, both in terms of what goods are demanded, and the means of acquiring these goods (such as shopping at off-peak hours or through delivery or drive-through services).

Sappinolji fillu footi saanja, ɗiɗi fu do ko larni kujeji je ɓe ɗon emma, be dabareji keɓɓugo kujeji ndu (bana soddugo ha wakati je kuje saɗɗay jur, mala gal yimɓe je wartirata ndu ha saare mala ha sallooɓe be moota.
Lastly, shipments of items from geographic areas severely affected by COVID-19 may be interrupted.An infectious disease preparedness and response plan can be used to guide protective actions.
Ha timminol, yarɓol kujeji diga wakkereji je COVID-19 ɗon memma be sembe footi darnotto. Jaahargal taskaram mala jabbuye ngam nyau footi naffa ngam fadugo kuɗe.

Plans address the levels of risk associated with various worksites and job tasks, including sources of exposure, risk factors arising from home and community settings, and risk factors of individual workers such as old age or chronic medical conditions.

Jaahargalji ɗon usta yahdeji sababu je yahidatta be wakkereji kugal fu be irin kuɗe man, bana hoore je ɗon sappini, kujeji je footi ɓesda sababuji ha saare ha cakka ummatore, be kujeji je footi ɓesda sababuji yimɓe je huwatta feere maɓɓe bana newugo mala nyau feere je ɗon tokkita.
They also outline controls necessary to address those risks, and contingency plans for situations that may arise as a result of outbreaks.
Ɓe wurtini bo'o aynolji ngam ustugo irin sababuji, be jaahargalji wattugo ha seera ngam ko footi ummina bana sappinol nyauji.
Infectious disease preparedness and response plans may be subject to national or subnational recommendations.
Taskaram be jaahargalji jabbuye ngam nyau je ɗon raɓɓa footi nasta nder feeloji lesdi mala lammorde.

Objectives for response to an outbreak include reducing transmission among staff, protecting people who are at higher risk for adverse health complications, maintaining business operations, and minimizing adverse effects on other entities in their supply chains.

Dabareji ngam jabbuye ha nyau ndu larni aynol sallinol ha huwooɓe, yimɓe je ɗon sukla do yimɓe feere je ɗon mari sababuji ngam nyaɗugo nyauji feere, tokkitindirol fillu, be ustugo sababuji feere ha wakkere feere ha nder yahde maɓɓe.
The disease severity in the community where the business is located affects the responses taken.
Nyaɗugo nyau ha nder ummatore je fillu ɗon wondi ɗon memma dabareji je hoosama.
The hierarchy of hazard controls is a framework widely used in occupational safety and health to group hazard controls by effectiveness.
Yaɓɓordeji aynol sababuji lati dabare je ɗon huwida ha wakkereji jam e jam ɓaandu ngam wurtinugo aynolji be geeɓe man e be naffuda man.
Where COVID-19 hazards cannot be eliminated, the most effective controls are engineering controls, followed by administrative controls, and lastly personal protective equipment.
Ha wakkere je footay itta sababuji COVID-19, aynolji kanduɗum lati aynollji injiiniya'en, tokkiti be aynol kugal, e ha ragare man kuje sudugo.
Engineering controls involve isolating employees from work-related hazards without relying on worker behavior, and can be the most cost-effective solution to implement.
Aynolji injiiniya larni wattugo huwooɓe ha seera be sababuji je larni kugal bila larugo gikku huwoowo, e footi wona dabare je ɓuri naffugo.
Administrative controls are changes in work policy or procedures that require action by the worker or employer.
Aynolji kugal lati saanjolji nder siyasa kugal mala laahalji je yiɗi hakkilo huwoowo mala jagorɗo.
Personal protective equipment (PPE) is considered less effective than engineering and administrative controls, but can help prevent some exposures.
Kujeji fadol ɓaandu (PPE) lati bana maray sembe do aynolji injiiniya'en be kugal, amma footi naffa ngam aynugo ha wakkere feere.

All types of PPE must be selected based upon the hazard to the worker, properly fitted as applicable (e.g., respirators), consistently and properly worn, regularly inspected, maintained, and replaced, as necessary, and properly removed, cleaned, and stored or disposed of to avoid contamination.

Kala PPE fu sey suɓɓa ndu do sababu ha huwoowo, je ɗon larti kanduɗum (bana ordoji fuffugo), ɗon ɓorni be lawol e tumtum, lartama, laɓɓi, e saanja to wodi naffuda be wakati, itta be lawol, lalla, siga mala sakkina ngam tato raɓɓa.
According to the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), lower exposure risk jobs have minimal occupational contact with the public and other coworkers.
Ha U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), kuɗe je wala sappinolji jur maray ngidol jur be ummatore mala be huwooɓe feere.

Basic infection prevention measures recommended for all workplaces include frequent and thorough hand washing, encouraging workers to stay home if they are sick, respiratory etiquette including covering coughs and sneezes, providing tissues and trash receptacles, preparing for telecommuting or staggered shifts if needed, discouraging workers from using others' tools and equipment, and maintaining routine cleaning and disinfecting of the work environment.

Dabareji aynol nyau je aranool je feelama ha wakkere kugal fu larni lallugo juɗe boɗɗum e ha wakati fu, sembintinugo huwooɓe ngam wondugo ha saare to ɓe ɗon nyauɗo, laɓɓinugo lawol pofɗe gal suddugo sondaru be ɓislol, hokkugo leepolji be tassawo sakkinugo cuddi, taskugo ngam saanjol baabe jonde mala eggol to wodi haaje man, mbarugo jokke ha huwooɓe tato ɓe huwida be kuje mala ordo yimɓe feere, be laɓɓugo e laɓɓinugo wakkere kugal.
Prompt identification and isolation of potentially infectious individuals is a critical step in protecting workers, customers, visitors, and others at a worksite.
Maandugo law e wattugo ha seera yimɓe je bana mari nyau lati yaɓɓorde kanduɗum nder fadol huwooɓe, soddooɓe, ngilloɓe, be feere'en ha wakkere kugal.

The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) recommends that employees who have symptoms of acute respiratory illness are to stay home until they are free of fever, signs of a fever, and any other symptoms for at least 24 hours without the use of fever-reducing or other symptom-altering medicines, and that sick leave policies are flexible, permit employees to stay home to care for a sick family member, and that employees are aware of these policies.

Ɗowirɗe Aynol e Lartol Jam Ɓaandu (CDC) Lesɗe America ɗon feela yo'o huwooɓe je mari mandolji nyau pofɗe je bana nyaɗay wonda ha saare sey to ɓaandu maɓɓe wullata fahin, mandolji wullol ɓaandu, mala mandolji feere wanngatta fahin ha ɓawo njamdi 24 bila hoosugo lekki ustugo wullol ɓaandu mala mandolji feere, e yo'o siwtare ngam nyau caɗɗay, hokka jarfuye ha huwooɓe wonda saare ngam suklugo do jeeyaɗo saare maɓɓe je ɗon nyauɗo ha saare, e je howooɓe aandi siyasaji ndu.

According to OSHA, medium exposure risk jobs include those that require frequent or close contact within six feet (1.8 m) of people who are not known or suspected COVID-19 patients, but may be infected with SARS-CoV-2 due to ongoing community transmission around the business location, or because the individual has recent international travel to a location with widespread COVID-19 transmission.

Ha OSHA, kuɗe je ɗon mari sababuji deydey larni ɓe'en je yiɗi ɓadittol yimɓe nder kosɗe joowey e go'o (1.8 m) je aandi mala je footi mara nyau COVID-19, amma footi nanga nyau SARS-CoV-2 ngam sallinol ummatore ha tarde wakkere filluji, mala ngam goɗɗo neeɓay je warti jaahangal ha lesdi feere be sallinol COVID-19.

These include workers who have contact with the general public such as in schools, high-population-density work environments, and some high-volume retail settings.Engineering controls for this and higher risk groups include installing high-efficiency air filters, increasing ventilation rates, installing physical barriers such as clear plastic sneeze guards, and installing a drive-through window for customer service.Administrative controls for this and higher risk groups include encouraging sick workers to stay at home, replacing face-to-face meetings with virtual communications, establishing staggered shifts, discontinuing nonessential travel to locations with ongoing COVID-19 outbreaks, developing emergency communications plans including a forum for answering workers’ concerns, providing workers with up-to-date education and training on COVID-19 risk factors and protective behaviors, training workers who need to use protecting clothing and equipment how to use it, providing resources and a work environment that promotes personal hygiene, requiring regular hand washing, limiting customers' and the public's access to the worksite, and posting signage about hand washing and other COVID-19 protective measures.Depending on the work task, workers with at least medium exposure risk may need to wear personal protective equipment including some combination of gloves, a gown, a face shield or face mask, or goggles.

Ndu larni huwooɓe je ngidi be ummatore bana jaangirdeji, wakkere kugal je ɗon heewi be yimɓe, be wakkereji sippitolji je kujeji ɗon ruffi ha ton jur. Aynolji injiiniya'en ngam kanjuum be geeɓeji je ɗon mari sababu manga ngam nangugo nyau larni wattugo kujeji laɓɓinugo hendu, ɓesdugo hendu, wattugo keleewolji bana leeda tardugo kuje, e wattugo dammuɗe do moota sippolji. Aynolji kugal je kanjuum be geeɓeji je mari sababuji manga ngam raɓɓugo nyau larni sembintinugo huwooɓe je nyauɗo wonnda ha saare, waylittugo kawtalji je gite nder gite be ngewte gal ordo, wattugo suudu je footi egga ndu, darnugo jaahangalji je wala naffuda ha wakkereji je nyau COVID-19 ɗon ton, wurtinugo jaahargalji ngewte jaaawal be daaldal hokkugo matinolji keese do sababuji be gikku fadol COVID-19, ekkitugo kugal ha huwooɓe je yiɗi ɓornugo limse be kujeji fadol, hokkugo dabareji be wakkere kugal je yardi laɓɓinol, lallugo juɗe, ustugo nastirde soddooɓe be ummatore ha wakkere kugal, e ɓiilugo foto noy lallugo juɗe be dabareji sudol feere ngam COVID-19. Do irin kugal man, huwooɓe je mari sabajuji raɓɓugo je deydey sey ɓorna kujeji fadol bana kuje suddugo juɗe, ngapaleewol, darugal yeeso mala leepol suddugo yeeso, mala goggleji.
Workers in this risk group rarely require use of respirators.
Huwooɓe ha nder geeɓe ndu mari haaje ordoji fuffugo.

If a person becomes sick on an airplane, proper controls to protect workers and other passengers include separating the sick person from others by a distance of 6 feet, designating one crew member to serve the sick person, and offering a face mask to the sick person or asking the sick person to cover their mouth and nose with tissues when coughing or sneezing.

To goɗɗo do'i nyau ha nder pireewol, aynolji kanduɗum ngam aynugo huwooɓe be sallooɓe feere larni wattugo nyauɗo ha seera be yimɓe feere, dayugo deydey kosɗe 6, suɓɓugo goɗɗo gooto cakka maɓɓe sukla do nyauɗo ndu, e hokka leepol suddugo yeeso ha nyauɗo mala emmugo nyauɗo ndu sudda hunduko mako be kine mako be leepol to o ɗon sonda mala ɓisla.

Cabin crew should wear disposable medical gloves when tending to a sick traveler or touching body fluids or potentially contaminated surfaces, and possibly additional personal protective equipment if the sick traveler has fever, persistent cough, or difficulty breathing.

Geeɓe Kabin sey ɓorna kuje suddugo juɗe je o sakkina ha ɓawo suklugo do nyauɗo je ɗon waɗa jaahangal ndu mala memmugo illam ɓaandu mala baabe je raɓɓotto, to footi waɗa be kujeji fadol feere to nyauɗo ndu mari wullol ɓaandu, sondaru je timmata mala saɗirma nder pofɗe.

Gloves and other disposable items should be disposed of in a biohazard bag, and contaminated surfaces should be cleaned and disinfected afterwards.For commercial shipping, including cruise ships and other passenger vessels, hazard controls include postponing travel when sick, and self-isolating and informing the onboard medical center immediately if one develops a fever or other symptoms while on board.

Kujeji suddugo juɗe sey sakkina ha nder buuhu je joggugo irin kujeji ndu, e baabe je ɗon raɓɓi sey laɓɓina ndu e laɓɓa ndu. Ko larni kombeewol hortol kujeji fillu, bana kombeewol jaahangal be kombeewolji feere je roondatta yimɓe, aynolji nyau larni yarɓol jaahangol to goɗɗo man nyauɗo, wondugo ha seera e matinugo yimɓe je suklata do jam ɓaandu to a ɗon matti gul

Ideally, medical follow-up should occur in the isolated person's cabin.For schools and childcare facilities, CDC recommends short-term closure to clean or disinfect if an infected person has been in a school building regardless of community spread.

Ha woɗɗa, aynol ndu sallan no ha nder suudu je wati ha seera. Ko larni jaangirdeji be wakkere jo'inugo ɓikkon, CDC ɗon feela maɓɓolji ha nder wakati seeɗa ngam laɓɓugo mala laɓɓinugo to goɗɗo je mari nyau wondi no ha suudu jaangirde bila larugo sankittol cakka ummatore.

When there is minimal to moderate community transmission, social distancing strategies can be implemented such as canceling field trips, assemblies, and other large gatherings such as physical education or choir classes or meals in a cafeteria, increasing the space between desks, staggering arrival and dismissal times, limiting nonessential visitors, and using a separate health office location for children with flu-like symptoms.

To wodi sallinol seeɗa ha deydey ummatore, dabare dayugo ummatore footi naffa bana darnugo jaahangal ngilli, mofturdeji, be hawtirdeji maungel bana waɗugo espor, yimmugo mala nyammugo ha ccuɗi nyamɗe, ɓesdugo baabe ha cakka koroomje, ustugo wakati yottugo be dillugo, haɗɗugo ngilli je walla naffuda, hoosugo suudu jam ɓaandu ɓikkon je feere ɓe'en je bana mari mandolji ndamba.

When there is substantial transmission in the local community, in addition to social distancing strategies, extended school dismissals may be considered.For law enforcement personnel performing daily routine activities, the immediate health risk is considered low by CDC.

To wodi sallinol arandere ha nder ummatore wakkere, ha ɓawo dabareji dayugo ummatore, wakati maɓɓolji jaangirde footi ɓesdama. Ko larni yimɓe umrore je ɗon ayna do ko ɗon salla ko wetti fu, sababu jam ɓaandu je law hoccama gal CDC.

Law enforcement officials who must make contact with individuals confirmed or suspected to have COVID-19 are recommended to follow the same guidelines as emergency medical technicians, including proper personal protective equipment.
Yimɓe umrore ngidan be yimɓe je ɗon mari mala je footi mara nyau COVID-19 feelama ngam tokkugo tawretaji je huwooɓe jam ɓaandu ɗon tokka, bana ɓornugo kujeji fadol.

If close contact occurs during apprehension, workers should clean and disinfect their duty belt and gear prior to reuse using a household cleaning spray or wipe, and follow standard operating procedures for the containment and disposal of used PPE and for containing and laundering clothes.

To waɗi ɓe hawti ha wakati nangol ngu, huwooɓe sey laɓɓa e laɓɓina kanda maɓɓe je kugal be kujeji maɓɓe hiddeko huwugo ba man fahin sey fuffa kuje lallugo saare mala sufta, e tokka laahalji kugal je ɗon aandin ko larni siggugo be sakkinugo PPE e je joggotto mala lottugo limse.
OSHA considers certain healthcare and mortuary workers to be at high or very high categories of exposure risk.
OSHA ɗon hocca huwooɓe do jam ɓaandu be huwooɓe do mayɓe bana ɗon nde geeɓe je sababuji mauni mala mauni masitin.
High exposure risk jobs include healthcare delivery, support, laboratory, and medical transport workers who are exposed to known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
Kuɗe je sababuji lati maungel larni huwooɓe suklare do jam ɓaandu, wallende, suudu lartol, be hortol jam ɓandu je wondi be nyauɓe je mari mala je footi mara COVID-19.
These become very high exposure risk if workers perform aerosol-generating procedures on, or collect or handle specimens from, known or suspected COVID-19 patients.
Latan sababu je mauni masin to huwooɓe huwi be laahal fuffugo aerosol do, mala moftugo mala memmugo leekuji ha, yimɓe je ɗon aandi mala footi mara nyau COVID-19.
Aerosol-generating procedures include intubation, cough induction procedures, bronchoscopies, some dental procedures and exams, or invasive specimen collection.
Laahalji fuufugo aerosol larni sallinugo kuje gal daande, laahalji umminugo sondaru, bronchoscopiji, jaahargal e lartol ni'e feere, mala mofturde leeku.

High exposure risk mortuary jobs include workers involved in preparing the bodies of people who had known or suspected cases of COVID-19 at the time of their death; these become very high exposure risk if they perform an autopsy.Additional engineering controls for these risk groups include isolation rooms for patients with known or suspected COVID-19, including when aerosol-generating procedures are performed.

Kuɗe sababu huwooɓe do mayɓe larni taskugo wade yimɓe je aandi mari mala footi mari nyau COVID-19 ha wakati mayde maɓɓe; ndu lati bana sababu maungel masitin to ɓe ɗon seeka wade ngam larugo ko mbari mo. Aynolji injiiniya'en ɓesdotto ha iirin geeɓe sababu ndu bana cuuɗi wondugo seera nyauɓe je aandi don mari mala je footi mara nyau COVID-19, bana to laahalji fuffugo aerosol ɗon larni.
Specialized negative pressure ventilation may be appropriate in some healthcare and mortuary settings.
Fuffugo hendu je feerejo footi naffa ha wakkereji jam ɓaandu feere be suklugo do wade.
Specimens should be handled with Biosafety Level 3 precautions.
Leekuji sey memmotto be dabareji hakkika Biosafety Level 3.

The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends that incoming patients be separated into distinct waiting areas depending on whether they are a suspected COVID-19 case.In addition to other PPE, OSHA recommends respirators for those who work within 6 feet of patients known to be, or suspected of being, infected with SARS-CoV-2, and those performing aerosol-generating procedures.

Geeɓe Jam Ɓaandu Duniyaru (WHO) ɗon feela yo'o nyauɓe je ɗon nasta sey wonda feere be feere ha nder wakkereji ndeenugo to ɓe footi mara nyau COVID-19. Ha ɓesdugo do PPE, OSHA ɗon feela ordoji fuffugo ha yimɓe je ɗon huwa nder kosɗe 6 nyauɓe je ɗon aandi mari, mala je tammi marugo SARS-CoV-2, be ɓe'en je ɗon ngaɗa laahalji fuffugo aerosol.

In the United States, NIOSH-approved N95 filtering facepiece respirators or better must be used in the context of a comprehensive, written respiratory protection program that includes fit-testing, training, and medical exams.
Ha Lesɗe America, leepol fuffugo N95 je NIOSH jaɓɓi mala je ɓuri sey huwa be majuum ha nder jaahargal fadol pofɗe fu, je ɗon windi bana lartol wawande, ekkitol, be lartolji nyau.

Other types of respirators can provide greater protection and improve worker comfort.The WHO does not recommend coveralls, as COVID-19 is a respiratory disease rather than being transmitted through bodily fluids.
Ordoji fuffugo feere footi hokka fadol je ɓuri e saklata huwoowo. WHO feelata limse je ɗon sudda ɓaandu fu ngam COVID-19 woni nyau pofɗe do nummol bana ɗon salla gal illam ɓaandu.
WHO recommends only a surgical mask for point-of-entry screening personnel.
WHO ɗon feela leepol suudugo yeeso seekowo ha huwooɓe nastirde suudu lekki.

For those who are collecting respiratory specimens from, caring for, or transporting COVID-19 patients without any aerosol-generating procedures, WHO recommends a surgical mask, goggles, or face shield, gown, and gloves.
Ko larni yimɓe je moftatta leekuji pofɗe ha, suklatta do, mala roondatta nyau
If an aerosol-generating procedure is performed, the surgical mask is replaced with an N95 or FFP2 respirator.
To laahal fuffugo aerosol huwidotto, leepol suddugo yeeso seekowo waylittama be ordo N95 mala FFP2.

Given that the global supply of PPE is insufficient, WHO recommends minimizing the need for PPE through telemedicine, physical barriers such as clear windows, allowing only those involved in direct care to enter a room with a COVID-19 patient, using only the PPE necessary for the specific task, continuing use of the same respirator without removing it while caring for multiple patients with the same diagnosis, monitoring and coordinating the PPE supply chain, and discouraging the use of masks for asymptomatic individuals.

Ngam tagle PPE ha nder duniyaru he'ay, WHO ɗon feela ustol haaje PPE gal lartol dayindi, keleewolji bana dammuɗe be darugal, je hokkatta jarfuye nastirde sna ha sukloɓe do nyauɓe COVID-19, huwidugo be PPE sna to kugal man ɗon, huwida be ordo je on ɗon mari bila ittugo ndu ha yakke suklugo do nyauɓe feere-feere je ɗon mari irin lartol ndu, aynugo e fadugo soddooɓe PPE, haɗɗugo
WHEREAS on March 4, 2020, I proclaimed a State of Emergency to exist in California as a result of the threat of COVID-19;
HA 4 Maars 2020, mi matini Dabare Jaawal wonda ha California bana sappinol raɓɓol COVID-19;
and WHEREAS in a short period of time, COVID-19 has rapidly spread throughout California, necessitating updated and more stringent guidance from federal, state, and local public health officials;
e HA wakati seeɗa ni, COVID-19 sankitti laugel ha nder California, be marugo haaje lartol be sappinol dabareji nyaɗum ha lesdi, ngomna, be arduɓe jam ɓaandu ummatore wakkere;

and WHEREAS for the preservation of public health and safety throughout the entire State of California, I find it necessary for all Californians to heed the State public health directives from the Department of Public Health.
e HA ko larni aynugo jam ɓaandu e jam ummatore ha nder lesdi California fu, mi tawi boɗɗe ha yimɓe California fu ɗowtina matinolji jam ɓaandu Ngomna ha ummatore ga Geeɓe Jam Ɓaandu.

NOW, THEREFORE, I, GAVIN NEWSOM, Governor of the State of California, in accordance with the authority vested in me by the State Constitution and statutes of the State of California, and in particular, Government Code sections 8567, 8627, and 8665 do hereby issue the following Order to become effective immediately:

JONTA BO'O, MIN, GAVIN NEWSOM, Ngomna California, be sembe je Umrore be tawretaji Lesdi California hooki yam, e ɓurna bo'o Government Code geeɓe 8567, 8627, be 8665 ɗon wurtina Tawreta ndu e hoccan sembe diga jonta:
IT IS HEREBY ORDERED THAT:
NDA KO MI HASDI:

1) To preserve the public health and safety, and to ensure the healthcare delivery system is capable of serving all, and prioritizing those at the highest risk and vulnerability, all residents are directed to immediately heed the current State public health directives, which I ordered the Department of Public Health to develop for the current statewide status of COVID-19.

1) Aynugo jamɗu e jam ummatore, e dabare suklare do jam ɓaandu footi sukla do ko moy fu, be suklugo ɓurna do ɓe'e je mari sababuji maungel masitin be je wala sembe, ummatore fu sey ɗowtina matinolji Ngomna do jam ɓaandu ndu diga jonta, je mi jarfi Geeɓe Jam Ɓaandu Ummatore wurtinugo ngam ko
Those directives are consistent with the March 19, 2020, Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers During COVID-19 Response, found at: https://covid19.ca.gov/.
Dabareji ndu ɗon yahida be Memorandum on Identification of Essential Critical Infrastructure Workers During COVID-19 Response je 19 Maars 2020, je tawama ha: https://covid19.ca.gov/.
ORDER OF THE STATE PUBLIC HEALTH OFFICER
TAWRETA ARDUƊO JAM ƁAANDU LESDI

To protect public health, I as State Public Health Officer and Director of the California Department of Public Health order all individuals living in the State of California to stay home or at their place of residence except as needed to maintain continuity of operations of the federal critical infrastructure sectors, as outlined at https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.

Ngam fadugo jam ɓaandu ummatore, Min Arduɗo Jam Ɓaandu Lesdi be Ɗowuwo Geeɓe Jam Ɓaandu hasdi ko moy fu je nyeeɗatta ha do Lesdi California joɗɗa ha saare mala ha wakkere jonde mako sna to ngam tokkitugo kugal lesdi je larni kujeji yahde lesdi, bana ɗon limti ha https://www.cisa.gov/critical-infrastructure-sectors.

In addition, and in consultation with the Director of the Governor's Office of Emergency Services, I may designate additional sectors as critical in order to protect the health and well-being of all Californians.
Ha ɓesdugo, e be ngewte be Ɗowuwo Suudu Ngomna je Suklata do Kuɗe Jaawal, footi mi suɓɓa wakkereji feere to wodi haaje ngam fadugo jam ɓaandu e jam woore jeeyaɓe California.

Pursuant to the authority under the Health and Safety Code 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 and 120150, this order is to go into effect immediately and shall stay in effect until further notice.
Bana ɗon limti ha nder Umrore Jam Ɓaandu e Jam 120125, 120140, 131080, 120130(c), 120135, 120145, 120175 be 120150, tawreta ndu hoccan sembe diga jonta e tokkitan ha to batakkewol feere wurti.

The federal government has identified 16 critical infrastructure sectors whose assets, systems, and networks, whether physical or virtual, are considered so vital to the United States that their incapacitation or destruction would have a debilitating effect on security, economic security, public health or safety, or any combination thereof.

Ngomna lesdi maandi wakkereji je ɗon mari saɗirmaji 16 je kuɗe, dabareji, be kawtirdeji maɓɓe, ko je ɗon lara be je ko laratta, lati bana kanduɗum ha Lesɗe America je sembe maɓɓe timmi mala woni ɗon mari sababu do jam, jam siggorde, jam ɓaandu mala jam, mala hawtirde feere.
I order that Californians working in these 16 critical infrastructure sectors may continue their work because of the importance of these sectors to Californians' health and well-being.
Mi ɗon hasda yo'o ummatore California je ɗon huwa ha wakereji sababu 16 ndu footi tokkita kuɗe maɓɓe ngam naffuda wakkereji ndu ha jam ɓaandu e jam yimɓe California.
This Order is being issued to protect the public health of Californians.
Tawreta ndu wurtutto ngam fadugo jam ɓaandu yimɓe California.
The California Department of Public Health looks to establish consistency across the state in order to ensure that we mitigate the impact of COVID-19.
Geeɓe Jam Ɓaandu Ummatore yiɗi teffugo tokkitol ha nder lesdi ngam heɓɓa en usta sembe COVID-19.
Our goal is simple, we want to bend the curve, and disrupt the spread of the virus.
Kugal amin ɗon kooyɗum, min yiɗi ustugo yahde, e darnugo sankittol viriis.
The supply chain must continue, and Californians must have access to such necessities as food, prescriptions, and health care.
Addugo kujeji sey tokkita, e ummatore California sey mara dabare heɓɓugo irin kujeji ndu bana nyamdu ndu, lekki, jam ɓaandu.

When people need to leave their homes or places of residence, whether to obtain or perform the functions above, or to otherwise facilitate authorized necessary activities, they should at all times practice social distancing.
To yimɓe yiɗi wurtugo saare maɓɓe mala wakkere jonde maɓɓe, temma ngam heɓɓugo mala waɗugo ko ɗon limti ha do ndu, mala latinugo kuɗe je ɗon jarfi kooyɗum, sey ko moy fu daya oya be oya.

2) The healthcare delivery system shall prioritize services to serving those who are the sickest and shall prioritize resources, including personal protective equipment, for the providers providing direct care to them.
2) Dabare suklare do jam ɓandu hokkan arandere sa'a ha kuɗe je suklatta do yimɓe je ɓuri nyaugo e hokkan bo'o sa'a ha dabareji, bana kujeji fadol, ha huwoɓe je suklatta do maɓɓe.
3) The Office of Emergency Services is directed to take necessary steps to ensure compliance with this Order.
3) Ɗowirɗ e Kuɗe Jaawal feelama ngam hoosugo yaɓɓordeji ngam ɗowtinugo ha Tawreta ndu.
4) This Order shall be enforceable pursuant to California law, including, but not limited to, Government Code section 8665.
4) Tawreta ndu hoosan sembe bana ko ɗon limti ha nder umrore California, amma haɗɗay ha ton tan, Government Code geeɓe 8665.
IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that as soon as hereafter possible, this Order be filed in the Office of the Secretary of State and that widespread publicity and notice be given of this Order.
LATI HASDOTTO BO'O bana ko wowi, Tawreta ndu neldotto ha Ɗowirɗe Windowo Lesdi e sankittoto gal matinolji do Tawreta ndu.

This Order is not intended to, and does not, create any rights or benefits, substantive or procedural, enforceable at law or in equity, against the State of California, its agencies, departments, entities, officers, employees, or any other person.

Tawreta ndu wurti ngam, e footay, wangina jarfuji mala ribaji, je wurtatta nder ton mala gal laahal, je yahidata be umrore be wondugo kalkal, do Lesdi California, wakkereji, geeɓeji, toɓeji, arduɓe, huwooɓe ma maɓɓe mala yimɓe feere.
IN WITNESS WHEREOF I have hereunto set my hand and caused the Great Seal of the State of California to be affixed this 19th day of March 2020.
BANA SEEDOWO KANJUUM mi ɗon waɗa jungo am do man be Mandirɗum Manga Lesdi California do ton ha nyalade 19 Maars 2020 ndu.
FROM: Katherine Maher, Wikimedia Foundation CEO
DIGA: Katherine Maher, Wikimedia Foundation CEO
TO: All Wikimedia Foundation staff
HA : Geeɓe Wikimedia Foundation fu
SUBJECT LINE: [Covid-19] Lightening the load and preparing for the future
HOORE NGEWTE: [Covid-19] Ustugo nyau be taskugo jaango
SEND DATE/TIME: 14 March, 2020, 00:24 UTC
WAKATI/WAKKERE NELDOL: 14 Maars, 2020, 00:24 UTC
LICENSING: CC0: No rights reserved
LICENSING: CC0: No rights reserved
We find ourselves in remarkable circumstances this month.
Min tawi hoore amin ha nder larulaji maungel lewru ndu.
The COVID-19 epidemic is something that makes clear our global human interconnectedness and the responsibilities we have to one another.
Nyau COVID-19 lati kuje feere ɗon laɓɓina yo'o jonde amin ɓi'i adama sey joɗɗida oya be oya ngam en ɗon larni fu ngam ko ɗon salla jonta ndu.

We don’t have precedent for its challenges, but we do know that our best response relies on the sort of global empathy, cooperation, and community building that sits at the heart of this organization.
Min wala kujeji sappinol do man, amma min aandi yo'o jabbuye amin je kanduɗum joɗɗi do jurminol uya be oya, huwidol, be kugal nder ummatore je woni cakkare jonde ndu.
The camaraderie and care we have seen among all of our colleagues over email, calls, and chats is a remarkable validation of the incredible humans we are fortunate enough to work with.
Sobiraaku be suklare do ummatore je en lari ha kunde derɗiraaɓe amin gal emailji, ewnolji, be ngewte lati kugal kanduɗum je ɓi'i adama mari sa'a masin je en huwida be man.
I couldn’t be more grateful and proud to count you all as colleagues.
Footay mi yetta mon e seeya do moɗon ɓuri ɗo ngam limmugo do moɗon derɗiraaɓe.
Last week, someone shared with me their appreciation for our work.
Ha asawere je sallingo, goɗɗo feere sendi be am sembintinugo kugal amin.
They reminded me how meaningful it is for the world to be able to turn to Wikipedia right now, and what a powerful symbol it is for this critical resource to remain online and available to all.
O siftorini yam noy lati kanduɗum ha duniyaru ngam waylittugo gal Wikipedia jonta ndu, e lati mandol sembe ngam dabare ndu wona do hawo e ko moy fu footi heɓɓa ɗum.
Your work makes this possible, whether you keep the sites stay up or our colleagues paid or our communities safe.
Kugal moɗon ɗon ngaɗa ɗum footi salla, ko to gal aynugo siteji wonda finditti mala derɗiraaɓe yoɓɓi mala ummatoji jam.
The world needs the information that Wikipedia provides, now more than ever.
Duniyaru mari haaje matinolji je Wikipedia ɗon hokka, jonta ɓuri je sallingo.
This is a moment in which not only what we do, but how we do it, will make a meaningful impact on the world.
Ndu lati wakati ja na ko en waɗatta tan, amma noy en ɗon ngaɗa ɗum, waɗan feeretirol do duniyaru.
Because of the importance of this mission and your role in it, we will be making some significant adjustments to how we work together, starting this coming week.
Ngam daraja kugal ndu be ko on waɗatta ha nder man, en laritan dabareji amin do noy huwidugo, fuɗɗam ha asawere je warata.
Adjustments to our work and schedules
Lartolji do kugal amin be jaahargalji
As Robyn mentioned previously, the c-team met last night to discuss our approach and schedule for the coming days and months.
Bana Robyn matini seeɗa, c-team hawti kenya ngam ngewtidugo dabare be jaahargal amin je balɗe be lebbi je warango.
In that conversation, we considered what we thought would be an appropriate response to what we’re facing and the best way to keep the organization sustainable during this time.
Ha nder ngewte ndu, en hoosi ko en tammi wonan jabbol je kanduɗum do ko en ɗon lara jonta be dabare je ɓuri naffugo ngam yahde ummatore ha wakati ndu.
Overwhelmingly we wanted to remove stress and support our mission for the long term.
Be seeyo fahin, min yiɗi ittugo tampere e fada kugal amin ngam ha abada.
If you need to dial back, that’s okay.
To on yiɗi lorugo, bismila.
For all staff, contractors, and contract workers:
Ha geeɓe fu, hokkowo kugal, be huwooɓe:
our daily working expectations will be about 4 hours a day, or 20 hours a week until further notice.
kugal amin je en footi waɗa ko wetti fu ɗon gal njamɗe 4 nder balɗe, mala njamɗe 20 nder asawere ha matinol feere.
We’re not declaring a holiday - if you are able to work more normal hours, the mission can use you.
En matinay siwtare, to on footi huwa ha gaɗɗa njamɗe je ɗon aandi, kugal footi huwida be mon.
However, the world is unpredictable right now, and whether you need to care for loved ones, get groceries, or go to the doctor, your well-being is our priority.
Amma, ha nder duniyaru je jonta ndu, footay goɗɗo famma ko footi yotta jaango, e to a yiɗi suklugo do ngiɗaɗo maɗa, sodda kujeji, mala yaha ha lekkitajo, jam ɓandu moɗon lati kugal amin.
We are not tracking your time.
En emmatta ko on waɗi be wakati moɗon.
If you are sick, do not work.
To a nyauɗo, ta huwu.
This should go without saying, but we’re saying it.
En maray no haaje yeccugo ɗum, amma en ɗon yecca ɗum.
No sick days or PTO required - just tell your manager and help your team revise calendars and schedules to make sure key areas of work are covered.
Wala balɗe nyau mala PTO je en emmatta, matinu arduɗo ma e wallu geeɓe ma larta jaahargalji ngam fammugo to wakkereji kanduɗum ɗon suddu.
(If you are diagnosed positive for COVID-19, please let Bryan within T&C Ops know so T&C can help with support and make sure your situation gets appropriate attention from management).
(To a lartama bana a mari nyau COVID-19, useni matinu Bryau nder T&C Ops ngam heɓɓa walla mon e aanda yo'o a ɗon jam e watta hakkilo ɗowirɗe do ma).
Hourly folks will be fully paid.
Yimɓe je huwatta nder njamdi heɓɓan ceede lewru maɓɓe.
We have already said, and are recommitting to honor our commitments to our contractors and hourly staff colleagues.
En yecci ɗum timmi,, e ɗon hasdi lartugo hasduji amin ha hokkooɓe kugal amin be derɗiraaɓe amin je ɗon huwa nder njamdi.
Everyone will be paid on the basis of their usual hours worked during normal circumstances.
Ko moy fi keɓɓan ceede lewru mako bana ko o ɗon no jaɓɓa ha wakati je wala jiɓɓol.
This includes if you are sick and unable to work.
Ko to a nyauɗo e footay a huwa.
If you want to work, we support you.
To a yiɗi huwugo, min wallan ma.
Many people use work as a way of channeling their stress with the world around us.
Yimɓe jur ɗon hoosa kugal bana dabare willugo nummolji maɓɓe nder duniyaru je jonta ndu.
What we do can be incredibly rewarding, especially during times like this.
Ko en ɗon waɗa ndu footi yoɓɓa be sembe, ɓurna be irin wakati bana je jonta.
Again, this is about your self-care.
Fahin, ndu larni suklugo do ma be hoore maɗa.
Our ask is that you communicate with your manager, so we know what to expect and can adjust accordingly.
Ewnandu amin lati yo'o on ngewta arduɗo moɗon , ngam heɓɓa ko en footi ndena e footi larta nder jaahargal amin.
Some work is considered essential.
Kugal feere lati bana kanduɗum.
There are some things that we must keep doing.
Wodi kujeji feere je sey tokkita waɗugo ɗum.
The SRE, HR Ops, Trust & Safety, and Fundraising teams (among others) do critical work that may need additional support.
SRE, HR Ops, Trust & Safety, be geeɓeji Hoosugo wallende (ha cakka feere'en) ɗon waɗa kugal kanduɗum je footi mara haaje wallende feere.
We’ll begin a process with all departments to assess current objectives and shift our focus to supporting what’s essential for our mission.
Min fuɗɗan laahal feere be geeɓeji fu ngam lartugo dabareji amin je jonta e woylitta kugal amin do ko ɓuri kanduɗum ngamm kugal amin.
There’s plenty to do for all of us, we just will all focus on the most essential projects.
Wodi kugal jur ngam ko moy fu, en suɓɓan kuɗe je ɓuri naffuda tawon.
Slowing now won’t hurt later.
Ɗaayugo jonta nawnata jaango.
We do not plan to go “double-time to catch up” once the pandemic has passed.
En tammay "ɓesdugo mon wakati nde ɗiɗi ngam jokkitugo" ha ɓawo nyau duniyaru ndu salli.
You will not be expected to work extra hours to meet deadlines which are now unrealistic.
On footay emmotto ngam ɓesdugo njamɗe feere ngam jokkittugo ko en waɗay jonta.
We accept that circumstances have changed, and will work to set new targets and timelines where appropriate.
Min aandi yo'o kujeji saanji, e en huwidan ngam lartugo dabareji amin be jaahargalji ha wakkere je naffan.
What happens with the APP (Annual Planning)?
Ko ɗon salla be APP (Jaahargal Hittande)?
To adjust to our new reality and daily working hour expectations, we intend to adjust the timeline for the delivery of our 2020-2021 Annual Plan.
Ngam lartugo kugal amin jonta be njamɗe ko en footi huwa ha nder balɗe, min yiɗi lartugo wakati wurtinol Jaahargal Hittande amin 2020-2021.

Our intention is to propose an extension of our 2019-2020 plan that allows more time for budgeting to allow employees to prioritize critical work, self-care, and care for loved ones while accommodating those who need or wish to work a reduced schedule over the next few weeks.

Ha nummol amin en yiɗi no juttinugo jaahargal 2019-2020 je ɗon hokka wakati jur ngam suɓɓugo ceede ngam hokkugo jarfuye ha huwooɓe lara kugal kanduɗum, suklugo do hoore maɓɓe, be suklare do ngiɗaɓe maɓɓe ha wakati man en hoosan ɓe'en je yiɗi nastugo mala je yiɗi ustugo jaahargal maɓɓe ha nder asaweji je warango.
This timeline extension greatly reduces current planning workloads and pressure across the whole organization.
Juttinol wakati ndu ustan be ɗuɗɗum jaahargal kuɗe be jaawal ha nder ummatore man fu.
We will introduce our proposal to the Board next week and will update delegates and teams on the next steps as soon as we have confirmation.
En sappinan ko en hasdi ha Arduɗo ha asawere je warango e matinan fadooɓe be geeɓeji ha yaɓɓorde je warango to en heɓɓi jabbol ni.
Thank you to the APP team for your leadership in this.
Min yetti geeɓe APP ngam fadol moɗon.
Office status, exposure, and cleaning
Wondugo ɗowirɗe, sappinol be laɓɓinol
Last week, we learned that one of our SF-based colleagues may have been exposed to the COVID-19 virus.
Ha asawere je sallingo, e ekkiti yo'o gooto cakka derɗiraaɓe amin je ɗon woni ha SF, hoore mako ɗon no sappini ha viriis COVID-19.
However, out of an abundance of caution, we employed an antiviral cleaning crew to disinfect all surfaces in the San Francisco office.
Amma, do hakkikaji amin fu, en hoosi geeɓe je suklatta do laɓɓugo e laɓɓinugo baabe fu je mari viriis ha ɗowirɗe San Francisco.
They utilized a hospital-grade anti-viral solution to disinfect every surface, as well as the lobby and elevator banks accessing our floor.
Geeɓe ndu huwidi be dabare je mbardugo viriisji je suudu lekki fu ɗon huwida be man ngam laɓɓinugo baabe, be nastirde, be kuje hortol ha do suudu feere.
The building is employing its own duty-of-care protocol utilizing products that support the safety of their tenants.
Mahdi ndu ɗon huwida be dabare laɓɓinol maɗa e ɗon huwida be kujeji je ɗon fada jam wonɗɓe.
We feel comfortable that the office will be well-prepared for when we decide to return.
Min ɗon seeyi ngam baabal kugal wonan taskuɗum do ndey en loratta.
Our DC office is located in a WeWork, which has shared its COVID-19 protocol with us and all DC-based staff members.
Baabal kugal amin je DC ha nder WeWork, je sendi dabare COVID-19 maɗa be amin be jeeyaɗo geeɓe DC.
As of last week, our DC office moved to a fully remote setup in line with the guidance shared with San Francisco.
Ha asawere je sallingo, suudu kugal amin je DC eggi ha wakkere je ɗon dayi masin je ɗon ɗowtina dabare je sendama be San Francisco.
As some of our NYC-based colleagues know, we have also been in discussion about leasing a location in Brooklyn.
Bana derɗiraaɓe amin je ɗon woni ha NYC, min ngewtidi bo'o do hoosugo suudu feere ha Brooklyn.
These discussions are continuing but may be delayed.
Ngewteji ndu ɗon tokkita amma footi ɗaaya.
Some of our colleagues are working remotely for the first time.
Derɗiraaɓe amin feere ɗon huwida diga dayindi nde arandere wakati.
Our long-time remote colleagues know that it can be an adjustment, and wanted to offer you some advice:
Derɗiraaɓe amin je je wawi huwidugo diga dayindi aandi yo'o footi wona lartol, e yiɗi hokkugo mon feeloji feere:
Limit the length of meetings to at most one or two hour increments.
Usta juttol kawtirolji ha ɗuɗɗum man njamdi gooto mala ɗiɗi.
If longer sessions are required, consider how they can be broken up over the course of several days.
To wodi haaje kawtirolji je ɓuri juttugo, lare noy en footi ta'a ɗum nder jur do balɗe jur.
Clearly define the meeting, have an agenda, and send reading materials in advance.
Hokke uja kawtal ndu, ko en ngewtataa do man, e nelde kujeji jaangugo be wakati
Make video the default, with tools like Google Docs and Zoom to facilitate live collaboration and connection.
Ngaɗe vidiyoji ragare man, be kujeji bana Google Docs be Zoom ngam latinugo huwidol be kawtirde kooyɗum.
Have a lead to facilitate every meeting, someone to monitor the chat for questions and track the speaker list, and someone to help take notes (or do collaborative note-taking).
Keeɓe ɗowuwo ngam kaja kawtal, goɗɗo je footi fada ngewte ngam emmolji e larta limtol mo je hoccata wolde, be goɗɗo ngam wallugo windugo ko je ɗon limti (mala huwida be windugo).
Send an email to tech support if you need a comfortable headset.
Neldu email ha wallende teknik to a mari haaji kuje heeɗitugo je boɗɗe.
Use your wellness reimbursement for snacks.
Hoose lorni jam woore mon ngam nyamɗe.
Join the #remoties channel in Slack to talk with your colleagues about distributed work
Jokke #remoties channel nder Slack ngam wolwugo be derɗiraaɓe moɗon do kugal je sedama
The HR Operations team is looking into webinar-based ergonomics guidance to support the increase in distributed work across the Foundation.
Geeɓe Kuɗe HR ɗon lara nder dabareji sappinol nder webinar ngam wallugo be kugal je ɗon sendi ha nder Foundation.
This past week we asked all community grant recipients to cancel Wikimedia-funded public events, such as editathons, until the WHO declares the pandemic to be over.
Ha nder asawere je sallingo en emmi jaɓɓoɓe ummatore fu willa kujeji ummatore je Wikimedia on hokki ceede, bana editathons, ha wakati to WHO matini yo'o nyau duniyaru ndu.

We let them know that we understood that our request for cancellations and other restrictions could make it impossible to complete their agreed-upon grant activities and that no one would be penalized for having to delay or modify those goals.
Min matiniɓe yo'o en fammi emmol amin do willolji be darnolji footi artira ɗum footay timmina kuɗe maɓɓe je ɓe hasdi do man e footay ɓe elta goɗɗo ngam o ɗaayini mala saanji ɗm.
This coming week we will follow up with additional guidance on Wikimania and other regional and thematic community conferences.
Ha nder asawere je warango en tamman tokkitugo be sappinol Wikimania be kawtiroolji be ngewte ummatore wakkere feere.
The general sentiment from around the global community seems to be both sadness at the disruption but relief at the clarity and ability to focus on their own communities, Wikimedia and otherwise.
Tammunde yimɓe fu ha nder ummatore lesdi fu woni bana nyurmende ngam darnol amma seeyo ngam laɓɓinol be wawande do ummatoji maɓɓe, Wikimedia be feere.
Going forward, the CRT is working to set up a page on Meta-Wiki to provide a space for the community to monitor the impact and follow our communications with them.
Tokkitugo, CRT ɗon huwa ngam wanginugo batakkewol do Meta-Wiki ngam hokkugo daaldal ha ummatore ngam fadugo sembe man e tokkitugo ngewte amin be maɓɓe.
Staying in touch around COVID-19 related issues
Wondugo do ko larni COVID-19.
We’ll be sending an invitation to your calendars for next Thursday, 14:00 UTC/07:00 PT for a special staff meeting.
En neldan ewnanduji ha jaahargalji moɗon Alaamisa je warango, 14:00 UTC/07:00 PT ngam kawtal geeɓe je feerejo.
We’ll use this time to share additional updates, answer your questions and spend some time connecting with each other.
En huwidan nder wakati ndu ngam sendugo lartolji feere, jabba do emmolji moɗon e majjina wakati seeɗa ngewtidugo oya be oya.
We’re in this together and here to help however we can.
Min ɗon ngondi nder man e en taski wallugo ko moy fu.
In the meantime, you can continue to find the information from this email, and all other essential COVID-19 related information, on Office Wiki.
Ha wakati feere, footi a tokkita heɓɓugo matinolji ngam email ndu be matinolji feere je kanduɗum je larni COVID-19, do Office Wiki.
The CRT will keep these pages updated and all the information in one place.
CRT lartan batakeji ndu be matinolji fu ha baabe gooto.
We are also working to maintain regular communications with staff who reside in countries that are currently significantly affected.
Min ɗon huwa bo'o ngam ngewteji je tumtum be geeɓe je wondi ha nder lesɗe je ɗon memmi masitin jonta.
If you have any questions about travel, events, a major workstream, or coverage challenge, or anything else you may need help with, please don’t hesitate to notify and work with the CRT.
To wodi emmol ma ɗon do jaahangal, kuɗe, kugal kanduɗum, mala larula ngam jokkitol, mala kuje feere je footi a mara haaje man, useni ta miije ngam matinugo e huwa be CRT.
We’re here to help provide support and liaise as needed.
Min ɗon wondi ngam wallugo be hawtugo yimɓe to wodi haaje.
If you have a confidential or sensitive matter, please email Bryan Judan - Director of HR International Global Operations.
To a wodi ngewte amana mala je ɗon kanduɗum, useni neldine email ha Bryan Judan - Ɗowuwo HR International Global Operations.
None of these changes should be seen as an abandonment of our work and obligations.
Wala gooto ha cakka saanjolji ndu wangan bana accugol kugal amin mala kuɗe amin.
Rather, they are a recognition that at this moment, our work and obligations will likely need to adapt in a way we have not in the past.
Amma, lati bana aandinol yo'o ha wakati nde, kugal amin be kuɗe amin sey wona lartama bana ko en meɗɗay sam.
These are the steps we believe are necessary to support this one another so that we can continue to work, provide our movement with the support they need, and the world with the service they rely on.
Ndu lati yaɓɓordeji je en tammi naffan nder wallugo oya be oya ngam heɓɓa tokkitugo huwugo, waallugo yahde amin be ko a mari haaje, be duniyaru fu be kuɗe je ɓe ɗn ndeni.
Our planned work will be there waiting for us when the time comes.
Kuɗe amin je en waɗi jaahargal wondan nder reenugo amin ha wakati man yotta.
For now, it is time to support one another and create space for the important work that will be coming in the weeks and potentially months ahead.
Jonta, lati wakati wallugo oya be oya e heɓɓa daaldal ngam kugal kanduɗum je waratta ha nder asaweji e temma nder leeɓi je warango.
We need all of you to make that happen, and so we need you all to take care of yourself and your families so that you can be at your best when the need arises.
Min mari haaje mon fu ngam heɓɓa kuje man yotta, nden kati min mari haaje mon fu ngam suklugo do moɗon be caalaje mon ngam ha on wona jam ha wakati je en ewnan mon.
Now, please -- wash your hands and don’t touch your face!
Jonta, useni -- lalle juɗe mon e ta memme yeeso moɗon!

Katherine, the CRT (Amanda K, Amy V, Bryan J, Doreen D, Gregory V, Jaime V, Joel L, Lynette L, Ryan M, and Tony S), and the rest of the Leadership Team (Grant I, Heather W, Jaime V, Janeen U, Lisa S, Robyn A, Ryan M, and Toby N).

Katherine, CRT (Amanda K, Amy V, Bryan J, Doreen D, Gregory V, Jaime V, Joel L, Lynette L, Ryan M, and Tony S), be luttuɗum Geeɓe Ardugo (Grant I, Heather W, Jaime V, Janeen U, Lisa S, Robyn A, Ryan M, be Toby N).
The SARS-CoV-2 virus is the cause of COVID-19 (coronavirus disease 2019), a contagious respiratory disease that was first identified in December 2019, in Wuhan, Hubei, China.
Viriis SARS-CoV-2 lati gilɗi je wadi COVID-19 (nyau koronaviriis 2019), nyau pofɗe je ɗon raɓɓa je tawama aranool man ha Desambre 2019, ha Wuhan, Hubei, Cayna.
The disease is a type of coronavirus, the same family that includes SARS, MERS, and some varieties of the common cold.
Nyau ndu ɗon nder asngol koronaviriis, saare gooto be SARS, MERS, irin ndambaji feere-feere.
It was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization (WHO) on 11 March 2020.
Matinama bana nyau duniyaru gal Geeɓe Jam Ɓaandu Duniyaru (WHO) ha 11 Maars 2020.
While much about COVID-19 is still unknown, preliminary data suggests that it is more virulent and contagious than the seasonal flu, and less virulent but more contagious than SARS and MERS.
Ha wakati je kujeji jur COVID-19 aandakke, matinolji aranool ɗon sappina yo'o ɓuri nyaɗugo e raɓɓugo do ndamba wakati, e lessi nyaɗugo amma ɓuri raɓɓugo do SARS be MERS.
Older people and those with underlying conditions are the most at risk of serious complications including death.
Ndotti'en be ɓe'en je ɗon mari nyau feere ɓuri marugo sababu nyaɗugo nyau be mayde.
Due to the spread of the disease, you are advised not to travel unless necessary, to avoid being infected, quarantined, or stranded by changing restrictions and cancelled flights.
Ngam sankittol nyau, on feelama ngam ta on waɗa jaahangal sna to wodi naffuda, ngam tato on nanga nyau ndu, wonda siggito ha seera, mala majja gal saanjol haɗɗolji be darnol pireewolji.
Avoid crowded places whenever possible.
Luttu wakkereji je ummatore ɗon mofti ha to to a footi.
This is not just to protect you, but also those you come in contact with.
Ndu na ngam fadugo mon tan, amma yimɓe je a ngidi be maɓɓe.
As it happens, you probably aren't missing much by staying home, as many attractions around the world are closing their doors to avoid spreading the disease.
Bana ɗon salla, walla ko on majjinata jur ngam wondugo ha saare, ngam baabe ngilli ɗuɗɗum ha nder duniyaru ɗon maɓɓa dammuɗe maɓɓe ngam darnugo sankittol nyau ndu.

If you do need to travel, take precautions as you would for other infections: wash your hands frequently, avoid touching your face, cough and sneeze into your elbow or a tissue, and avoid contact with sick people.

To a mari haaje waɗugo jaahangal, hakkilu bana a wawi ngam nyauji feere: lallu juɗe ma be wakati fu, ta memmu yeeso maɗa, sondu e ɓislu do cakkare jokke jungo maɗa mala nder leepol, e luttu yimɓe je ɗon nyauɗo.
Before traveling, read up on the extensive and fast-changing array of travel restrictions that have been imposed around the world.
Hiddeko a waɗa jaahangal, jaangu ko ɗon matini do man dabareji do jaahangal ɗon saanja umtum ha nder duniyaru.
After travel, monitor your health and consider self-isolation for two weeks to avoid transmitting the disease to others.
Ha ɓawo jaahangal lartu jam ɓaandu maɗa e lartu wondugo ha seera be hoore maɗa ngam ta a sallina nyau ha yimɓe feere.
Transportation from long-distance passenger flights to local buses has been curtailed or completely shut down in many countries due to low demand or government orders.
Hortol be pireewolji hoorugo yimɓe diga lesdi dayindi ha mootaji wakkereji ustotto mala darnotto fu ha nder lesɗe jur ngam emmolji be tawretaji ngomna'en.
Many international and regional borders are closed.
Keerolji lesɗe be wakkereji ɗuɗɗum maɓɓotto.
If you are away from home, and especially if you are in another country, consider returning home as soon as possible; this may get even more difficult as restrictions continue to change.
To a wonday no saare, e to a ɗon woni ha nder lesdi feere, haɓdu wartugo law; ndu footi lati caɗɗungel ngam darnolji ɗon tokkita.
In some cases it may simply not be possible, even if you're healthy and meet the legal requirements for entry.
Ha yakke feere ma footay waɗa sam, ko to a ɗon woni jam e mari jarfuji nastugo nder lesdi man.
If you can't find a way back to your country, contact your nearest embassy or consulate for assistance.
To footay a warta ha nder lesdi maɗa, jokkitu fadawo mala ngomna lesdi moɗon je ɗon ɓadi ngam wallende.
They may be able to organize an evacuation, identify non-regularly scheduled flights, or give you an emergency loan to pay for transport.
Footi ɓe taska hortol, teffa pireewool je nastay no nder jaahargal, mala hokka ma ceede jaawal ngam ha a yoɓɓa hortol maɗa.
In case they can't, make preparations in case you need to stay where you are for an extended period.
To ɓe footay ngaɗa ndu, tasku to bana a yiɗi joɗɗugo ha wakkere je a ɗon wondi ha ton nder wakati seeɗa.
If you do find a way back home, be prepared that it may be expensive, inconvenient, and have unusual restrictions (such as no checked baggage).
To a taway dabare wartugo saare, taskittu ngam footi nawa, bila feecugo, e marugo haɗɗolji je on woway be man (bana kujeji ma lartay).
As of early April 2020, the number of confirmed cases of COVID-19 is approaching one million.
Ha fuɗɗam Aviiril 2020, limgal nyauɓe COVID-19 ɓadi ni milionre.
Though the disease started in mainland China, it has spread around the world and China has fewer confirmed cases and deaths than several other countries.
Ko to nyau man fuɗɗi ha lesdi Cayna, sankitti ha nder duniyaru fu e Cayna ɗon mari nyauɓe je ɗon aandi mari be mayɓe seeɗa tan do lesɗe feere.
Europe is the new epicenter of the pandemic.
Erop lati ɓundu keese nyau duniyaru ndu.

All but a handful of countries have reported at least one case, with the highest numbers of reported cases in the United States, Spain, Italy, Germany, France, mainland China, Iran, and the United Kingdom.
Lesɗe fu sna ndego-ndego tan matini pettum man nyauɗo gooto, be limtol nyauɓe ha Lesɗe America, Spain, Italy, Jaamani, Faraansa, lesdi Cayna, Iran, be Lesɗe Inglisiya.
Local transmission is established in many countries in all major inhabited regions of the world except some Pacific island nations.
Sallinol ha wakkere wonotto ha nder lesɗe jur je yimɓe ɗon wondi jur ha wakkereji ndu ha nder duniyaru sna ha nder lesɗi je ɗon tardi be ndiyam ha Pacific.
(See updates from the WHO.)
(Laru lartolji matinolji WHO)
The full extent of the spread is uncertain, due in part to limited testing.
Fammugo sankittol nyau man footay aanda be fakatre, ngam lartolji je wonay jur.

Many countries are experiencing a severe shortage of test kits, and the authorities have not been able to test everybody who is at high risk, so the real number of cases is probably much higher than the official one.

Lesɗe jur ɗon mari larulaji ngam kujeji lartol ɗon timma, e yimɓe ngomna heɓɓay lartugo yimɓe fu je ɗon mari sababuji maungel, nden waɗi footay aanda limtol nyauɓe sna non ɓuran je ngomna'en ɗon hokka.
Countries also differ in their testing and reporting practices, so comparisons of the number of reported cases do not tell the full story of how the epidemic has progressed in different areas.
Lesɗe bo'o ɗon feere-feere nder dabareji lartol be matinol, nden kadi foondolji limtolji nyauɓe je ɗon matini hallata tariya do noy nyau man yahidi ha nder wakkereji feere.
The virus is transmitted through respiratory droplets and through objects.
Viriis ndu ɗon salla gal tuɗe pofɗe be kujeji feere.
The coronavirus is a relatively large virus, meaning it is not truly airborne: it will settle down in respiratory droplets.
Koronaviriis woni viriis je ɗon manga, bana wi'ugo yo'o wolwugo gonga sallay gal hendu: wondan ha nder daande gal tuɗe.
Staying two metres (six feet) away from other people is usually enough to prevent transmission through this route.
Wondugo ha metaa ɗiɗi (kosɗe joowey e go'o) be yimɓe feere he'an ngam sallinol gal lawol ngel.
Transmission from objects can happen, for example, if someone sneezes, touches a doorknob, and then other people touch the doorknob and then touch their faces.
Sallinol diga kujeji footi waɗa, bana sappinol, to goɗɗo ɓisli, memmi dammugal, e ha ɓawo man yimɓe feere memmi dammungal ngel e memma yeeso maɓɓe fahin.
The SARS-CoV-2 virus may last on cardboard for up to 24 hours and on plastic for up to 3 days.
Viriis SARS-CoV-2 footi neɓɓa do takkarde ha njamɗe 24 e do leeda ngam ha balɗe 3.
Transmission via the fecal–oral route may also be possible.
Sallinol diga buuwe ha hunduko footi salla bo'o.
Evidence suggests that COVID-19 is contagious even without symptoms, though to what extent is still being investigated.
Sappinolji ɗon wi'a yo'o COVID-19 ɗon raɓɓa ko to wala mandolji, nden kadi ndu lartotto ha deydey toy.
Common symptoms include a fever, dry cough, and fatigue.
Mandolji je ɓurna larni wullol ɓaandu, sondaru jorɓum, be tampere.
Other less common symptoms include shortness of breath, a sore throat, headache, muscle pain, or sputum production.
Mandolji feere larni pofɗe bana daran, huudure do daande, paaɓooje, nawol ɓaandu, mala illol ndamba.
Some patients have very mild symptoms, similar to a cold.
Nyauɓe feere ɗon mari mandolji je nyaɗay, bana ndamba.
Serious complications include pneumonia, acute respiratory distress syndrome, and multi-organ failure leading to disability or death.
Nyaɗugo nyau man larni pneumonia, nyau saɗirma nder pofɗe be kujeji ɓaandu je ɗon dara ko ɗon yara ha wade.
About 80% of infections result in mild symptoms, while the remaining may result in hospitalization.
Deydey 80% nyauji ɗon mari mandolji je nyaɗa, be luttuɗum man footi timmina ha suudi lekki.
Case fatality rate is estimated at 1-3% of infected individuals, most of whom are elderly with underlying health conditions.
Limtol mayde woni ha kunde 1-3% yimɓe je ɗon mari, ɓurna fu ndotti'en be nyauji feere.
The fatality rate is much higher for those over 70 but significantly lower for those under 40.
Limtol mayde yimɓe je ɓuri duɓɓi 70 ɓuri amma je yimɓe je maray duɓɓi 40 ɗon lessi.

Those most at risk of COVID-19 infection and serious complications are the elderly and those with weakened immune systems or underlying health conditions like cardiovascular disease, diabetes, hypertension, chronic respiratory disease, and cancer.

Yimɓe je ɗon mari sababu maungel be COVID-19 be mandolji je nyaɗum woni ndotti'en be yimɓe ɓaandu maɓɓe maray sembe mala mari nyauji feere bana nyau ɓernde, nyau sukar, nyau illol iyam be sembe, nyau pofɗe je ɗon tokkitta, sankara.
Not many cases are reported in children and most of these are mild or moderate, though a significant fraction do get pneumonia.
Nyauɓe je matinama limmay ɓikkon jur e ɓurna ɓe'en je ɗon be nyau man nyaday sam mala deydey ko do feere'en naangi pneumonia.
Occupationally, health care workers have higher risk compared to others with clusters of disease among workers and in health care settings.
Jemma be naange, huwooɓe do jam ɓaandu ɗon mari sababu je maungel to foondi be yimɓe feere be sammere nyau ha kunde huwooɓe be wakkereji jam ɓaandu.

The time between being exposed to the virus and the emergence of symptoms (incubation period) is typically between 2 and 14 days, though there has been one reported case in China where symptoms appeared 27 days after exposure.
Wakati ha kunde wondugo be viriis be fuɗɗam mandolji (wakati nuftol) ɗon ha cakka balɗe 2 be 14, ko to wodi no nyauɗo feere ha Cayna je mandolji nyau wangi ha ɓawo balɗe 27.
As of February 2020, the period of infectiousness is unknown, but is likely most significant when people are symptomatic.
Ha Feviriye 2020, wakkati raɓɓol aandakke, amma lati kanduɗum to yimɓe sappinata mandolji nyau ndu.
There is evidence of transmission from people who don't have symptoms, although to what extent is still being investigated.
Wodi sappinol sallinol diga yimɓe je maray mandolji, ko to ekkitol do ndu luggay sam nder teffol.
It is unclear whether it is possible to be reinfected with the virus after recovering from it the first time around.
Laɓɓay to footi goɗɗo je meɗɗi raɓɓi viriis footi nanga nyau man fahin ha ɓawo nyambittol.
Long-term effects for people who have recovered remain unclear, but there is evidence of reduced lung capacity in some recovered patients.
Sababuji je tolli yimɓe je nyamɓitti laɓɓay, amma woodi sappinol ustol sembe fuffu ha nyauɓe feere je nyamɓitti.
Testing for the virus usually consists of a swab inserted through the nose or a throat swab which is analysed in a laboratory for the virus.
Lartol viriis ɓurna fu larni kule hoosugo lekkuje je ɓe ɗon nastina gal kine mala gal daande je lartama ha nder suudu lartol ngam viriis.
The current "gold standard" test involves extracting the genetic material from the sample and analysing it for known genetic markers of the virus.
"Dabare kanduɗum" lartol larni wurtinol kujeji gene nder leeku e lartugo ndu ngam heɓɓugo toɓeji gene viriis je ɗon aandin.
There is no established test assessing for the virus or antibodies in the blood, although tests are being developed.
Wala lartol je ɗon sappina be fakatre wondugo viriis mala fadooɓe ɓaandu ha nder iyam ko to wodi lartolji do lawol.
There is no test to establish immunity to the virus.
Wala lartol je sappinata fadol ngam viriis ndu.
Many governments around the world have advised their citizens not to travel unnecessarily amid the pandemic.
Ngomna'en jur ha nder lesdi feeli ummatore maɓɓe ta ɓe waɗa jaahangal je wala naffuda ha wakati nyau duniyaru ndu.
Lots of airlines and package holidays are making it easy for you by waiving cancellation and change fees.
Geeɓeji jaahangalji ɗuɗɗum be caahuji siwtare ɗon walla mon be man ngam ɓe ɗon darna jaahangalji e ɗon ɓesda ceede hortol.
Particularly avoid cruise ship travel.
Ɓurna bo'o lutte kombeewol ngillugo.

Older travelers and those with underlying health conditions are most at risk and should avoid travel that puts them at risk, such as long plane flights, visits to crowded places, and especially cruises, even outside of severely affected areas.

Yimɓe je warti jaahangal be ɓe'en je mari nyauji feere ɗon mari sababu maungel e sey lutta jaahangal je lati sababu ha maɓɓe, bana jaahangal be pireewol ha lesdi dayindi, ngilli ha wakkereji je ɗon heewi be ummatore, e ɓurna fu kombeewolji, ko to ha yaasi wakkereji je nyau man memmi jur.
In affected areas, most experts recommend a practice known as social distancing.
Ha nder wakkereji je nyau man ɗon nyaɗi ha ton, ɓurna aandoɓe ɗon feela dayol ummatore.
This means minimising contact with others by keeping a distance of six feet or two meters from them and avoiding gathering together in groups.
Ndu yiɗi wi'ugo ustugo hawtirdeji be yimɓe feere gal dayugo be kosɗe joowey go'o mala metaa ɗiɗi be luttugo geeɓeji ummatore.
Some areas permit small groups; others prohibit all group gatherings.
Wakkereji feere ɗon jaɓɓa mofturdeji petpetel; feere'en ɗon haɗɗa mofturdeji fu.
Measures you are encouraged to take include working from home whenever possible, avoiding crowds and avoiding leaving your home unless absolutely necessary.
Dabareje je a ɗon feeli ngam hoosugo woni huwugo diga saare to footi waɗa, luttugo mofturde yimɓebe luttugo wurtugo saare ma to wala uja feere je ɗon kanduɗum.
If you must go out, try to stay at least 2 meters (6 feet) away from other people.
To a yiɗi wurtugo, wondugo pettum man metaa ɗiɗi (kosɗe ɗiɗi) be yimɓe feere.
In many places these measures are required.
Ha wakkereji jur dabareji ndu emmotto.
Follow hygiene practices like for flu prevention.
Tokkitu dabare laɓɓinol bana be aynol ndamba.
Frequently wash your hands with soap and warm water, and then dry your hands on a clean towel.
Lallu juɗe ma ha wakati fu be sabulu e nduyam gulɗam, nden yoru ndu be leepol je ɗo laɓɓi.
As coronaviruses are enveloped viruses, washing your hands with soap kills the virus by disrupting the mostly fat-based viral envelope.
Nde koronaviriisji lati viriisji je ɗon suddi, lallugo juɗe moɗon be sabulu ɗon mbarda viriis ndu gal ɓoorugo laaral ɓaandu maɗa je ɗon tardi be ɓeelere.
Effective hand washing requires rubbing your hands for at least 20 seconds.
Lallugo juɗe be lawol man yiɗi yiggugo juɗe pettum man nder segonji 20.
Drying your washed hands physically removes some germs from your skin (so don't skip that step, and don't share towels).
Yorugo juɗe mon je on lalli timmi be limse ɗon itta gilɗiji do ɓaandu moɗon (ta juwinu yaɓɓorde man, e ta sendu leepol ma be gooɗo feere).
If soap and water are not available, then use a >60% alcohol-based hand sanitizer.
To wala sabulu be ndiyam, hoosu kuje laɓɓinugo juɗe je on mari alkol >60%.

Alcohol is a quick germ-killer, but it's not quite instant, so this still requires the same 20 seconds of rubbing your hands together, making sure that every single scrap of skin gets wet, and then you have to wait about another minute, for the alcohol to completely dry.

Alkol lati mbarowo gilɗi je laugel, amma na jonta-jonta, kanjuum bo'o sey ndeena sekoni 20 be yiggugo juɗe maɗa, aandugo yo'o wala baabal je ɗon lutti do laaral ɓaandu maɗa, e ha ɓawo man sey a ndeena minti feere, heɓɓa alkol ndu yora fu.
Avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth with your hands.
Ta memmu gite, kine be hunduko maɗa be juɗe.
Most people touch their faces every few minutes, all day long.
Yimɓe ɓurna fu ɗon memma yeeso maɓɓe ha minti seeɗa, ha nyalla fu.
Try to do this less, and try to wash your hands before touching your face.
Foondu waɗugo ndu, e foondu lallugo juɗe ma hiddeko a meema yeeso maɗa.
Also, try to avoid touching surfaces you don't have to touch in the first place, at least with your bare hands.
Fahin bo'o, foondu ta memmu daaldalji, ta memmu ndu lau tawon, ta be jungo meere bo'o.
Cough and sneeze into your elbow or a tissue, and then immediately throw away the tissue and wash your hands.
Sondu e ɓislu ha nder cakkare jokke jungo ma mala ha nder leepol, e sakkinu leepol man e lallu juɗe ma.
Don't stand or sit near people who might be sick.
Ta wondu mala joɗɗu ha koomɓe yimɓe je footi wona nyauɗo.
Stay at least one meter – and ideally two meters (six feet) – away.
Wondu pettum man ha metaa gooto, sna non metaa ɗiɗi (kosɗe joowey e go'o), dayɗum.
As a quick way to eyeball this distance, imagine that you and the other person both reached your hands towards each other.
Foondugo be gite footi ngaɗa, waɗu bana an be goɗɗo je wondi ha yeeso ma, ko moy furtini jungo maɗa.
Could you touch the other person's hand without taking a step towards that person?
Footi a memma jungo mako to a waɗay yaɓɓorde gal yeeso na?
If the answer is yes, then you're too close.
To a jabbi oho, nden a ɗon ɓadi be mako.
Clean objects and surfaces that a lot of people touch, such as doorknobs, phones, and television remotes with regular household cleaner.
Laɓɓinu kujeji be daaldalji je yimɓe jur memmi, bana juɗe dammuɗe, telefonji, be telekomandji tele be kuje laɓɓinugo saare.
Disinfect the surfaces with a suitable disinfectant, such as diluted household bleach.
Laɓɓu daaldaji be kuje laɓɓugo je boɗɗe, bana wodezaavel.
Stay home when you are sick, and avoid contact with other people until your symptoms are gone.
Joɗɗu ha saare to a saatay, e ta wondu be yimɓe feere sey to mandolji nyau ndu timmi fu.
Do not share personal items that come into contact with saliva, such as toothbrushes, eating utensils, drinks, water bottles, and towels.
Ta sendu kujeji je hawti be tuɗe, bana kuje yiggugo ni'e, tassowo nyammugo, nyaarugo, koolobaji ndiyam, be leepolji be goɗɗo feere.
The practice of serving yourself from a common plate with your own chopsticks, common in China, should be avoided.
Hoosugo nyiiri ha nder tassowa gooto be sokkali, leegal ha Cayna, maɗɗa sam.
Greet people without touching them.
Sanu yimɓe bila memmugo ɓe.
Avoid hugs, kisses, handshakes, fist bumps, and any other contact.
Luttu harlolji, muɗɗugo hunduko, sanugo be juɗe, hawtugo juɗe, mala hawtugo feere.
If it's impossible to avoid contact, then wash your hands both before and after.
To footay waɗa on hawta be yimɓe, nden lallu juɗe ma hiddeko e ha ɓawo man.
It won't protect you from the coronavirus, but it will partially protect you from the flu, which remains a greater risk than COVID-19 in many areas.
Fadata ma ngam koronaviris, amma fadante ngam ndamba, je sababu nangugo ndu ɓuri je COVID-19 ha wakkereji jur.
This also saves you from unnecessary worry if you get the flu and think it might be the coronavirus.
Ndu ɗon hisaa ma ngam nummolji bana to a nangi ndamba a tamman yo'o ɗum koronaviriis.
If you are elderly or otherwise in a high-risk group and can be vaccinated for pneumonia, get that vaccination.
To a ndottijo mala a ɗon nder geeɓe yimɓe je ɗon mari sababu e a footi hoosugo baatal pneumonia, hoosu baatal man.

It won't protect you from viral pneumonia from COVID-19, but some COVID-19 patients have died of bacterial pneumonia that attacked their weakened lungs, so a pneumonia vaccination could save your life.

Fadata ma ngam gilɗi pneumonia be viriis je COVID-19, amma nyauɓe COVID-19 feere mayi ngamm bakteriyaji pneumonia je raɓɓi fuffu maɓɓe je maray no sembe timmi, ngam man kadi baatal pneumonia footi hisaa yonki moɗon.
Wearing masks is recommended for those who are suspected of carrying of disease and those who are in close contact with those infected.
Watugo leepol suddugo yeeso feelama ha yimɓe je bana mari nyau ndu be yimɓe ɗon wondi be yimɓe je ɗon mari nyau.
For those who are asymptomatic, the WHO does not recommend masks, though some national governments do.
Ko larni ɓe'en je sappinatta mandolji, WHO feelay leepolji suddugo yeeso, ko to ngomna'en lesɗe feere ɗon ngaɗa ndu.
Wearing a mask of some kind is required in some countries and cities in an effort to reduce community transmission.
