Wolde "teffol hiddeko suduu lekki" yiɗi wi'ugo yo'o ha wolde ekkitolji suudu lartolji bana in vitro be in vivi, je ɗon holla fuɗɗam yahde nder wanginugo baatal, lekki mbardugo viriis mala gilɗe be kosngal woore, bana sappinugo limtol hoccol be hallende, hiddeko hawtirde foondowo tokkita be lartol jam be naffuda ha neɗɗo.
Some antibiotics may be repurposed as COVID-19 treatments:
Antibiotikji feere footi lartama fahin ngam hurgugo COVID-19.
In March 2020, the main protease of the SARS-CoV-2 virus was identified as a target for post-infection drugs.
Ha Maars, arandere protease viriis SARS-CoV-2 maandotto bana lekki je hoosugo haɓawo hurgol.
This enzyme is essential to the host cell to reproduce the ribonucleic acid of the virus.
Neebam ndu kanduɗum ngam ha cell jaɓɓowo ngam waɗittugo ribonucleic acid viriis.
To find the enzyme, scientists used the genome published by Chinese researchers in January 2020 to isolate the main protease.
Ngam tawugo neebam ndu, aandooɓe hoosi genome je teffooɓe Cayna sappini ha Zaanviye 2020 ngam wurtinugo arandere protease.
As a potential combination therapy, they are used together in two Phase III arms of the 2020 global Solidarity project on COVID-19.
Bana kawtal lekki hurgol, ɓe hoccama ha juɗe ɗiɗi Yaɓɓorde III kuɗe Solidarity 2020 fu do COVID-19.
A preliminary study in China of combined lopinavir and ritonavir found no effect in people hospitalized for COVID-19.
Aranool ekkitol ha Cayna do hawtirde lopinavir be ritonavir taway sababu ha nyauɓe je wondi ha suudu lekki ngam COVID.

b'Drug repositioning (also known as drug repurposing, re-profiling, re-tasking or therapeutic switching) is the repurposing of an approved drug for the treatment of a different disease or medical condition than that for which it was originally developed.

Lortirugo b'Drug (je ɗon aandin bana laritugo lekki fahin, re-profiling, re-tasking mala saanjugo hurgol) woni laritugo hasduye aranool do lekki je ɗon jarfi timmi ngam hurgol nyau feere mala mandoji nyau feere je ngaɗotto do man aran.
This is one line of scientific research which is currently being pursued to develop safe and effective COVID-19 treatments.
Nda teffol aandal nder wolde gooto je ɗon tokkiti ngam wurtinugo lekki je ɗon jam e ɗon naffa ngam hurgugo nyau COVID-19.

Other research directions include the development of a COVID-19 vaccine and convalescent plasma transfusion.SARS-CoV-2 has about 66 druggable proteins, each of which has multiple ligand binding sites.
Dabareji teffol feere larni wanginol baatal be plasma COVID-19. SARS-CoV ɗon mari proteinji 66 je footi hawta be lekki, kala fu ɗon mari baabe hawtirugo jur.
Analyzing those binding sites provide the reasonable project of developing effective antiviral drug against COVID-19 proteins.
Lartugo baabe hawtirdeji ndu kuɗe kanduɗum nde do wurtinugo lekki mbardugo viriis je ɗon naffa ngam proteinji COVID-19.
Of the most important SARS-CoV-2 target proteins are papain-like protease, RNA dependent RNA polymerase, helicase, S protein, and ADP ribophosphatase.
Ha kunde proteinji SARS-CoV-2 je ɓuri woɗɗugo wondi protease je ɗon naandi papain, RNA dependent RNA polymerase, helicase, S protein, be ADP ribophosphatase.

Hussein A A, et al studied several candidate compounds which then optimized and analyzed for their skeleton similarity with the highest similar approved drugs in order to accelerate a potent anti-SARS-CoV-2 drug development in his preclinical study to be recommended in a clinical study design.

Hussein AA, et al. jaangi hawtirdeji lekki foondol je o hoosi e larti naandol suudu ha ɓawo man, e sappini naandolji jur be lekki je jarfotto ngam yaawinugo ko footi wona lekki kanduɗum je mbardatta SARS-CoV-2 ha nder ekkitol mako je hiddeko ngam feelugo ha nder dabare ekkitol ha suudu lekki.
Chloroquine is an anti-malarial medication that is also used against some auto-immune diseases.
Chloroquine woni lekki paaɓooje je ɗon feeli ngam nyauji feere bo'o.
On 18 March, the WHO announced that chloroquine and the related hydroxychloroquine would be among the four drugs studied as part of the Solidarity clinical trial.
Ha 18 Maars, WHO matini yo'o chloroquine be hydroxychloroquine footi wona ha cakka lekki je don nder ekkitol foondol ha suudu lekki Solidarity.

New York governor Andrew Cuomo announced that New York State trials of chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine would begin on 24 March.On 28 March, the FDA authorized the use of hydroxychloroquine sulfate and chloroquine phosphate under an Emergency Use Authorization (EUA).

Ngomna New York Andrew Cuomo matini yo'o foondolji New York State do chloroquine be hydroxychloroquine footi fuɗɗa ha 24 Maars. Ha 28 Maars, FDA jarfi hoccol hydroxychloroquine sulfate be chloroquine phosphate to wodi jaawal Emergency Use Authorization (EUA).

The treatment has not been approved by the FDA's clinical trials process and is authorized under the EUA only as an experimental treatment for emergency use in patients who are hospitalized but are not able to receive treatment in a clinical trial.

Laahal foondolji ha suudu lekki FDA jarfay hurgol ngol tawon e ɗon jarfi sna be hasduye EUA bana hurgol foondol tan to wodi jaawal be hurgol ha nyauɓe je wondi ha suudu lekki amma je footay keɓɓa hurgol ha lartol suudu lekki.
The CDC has said that "the use, dosing, or duration of hydroxychloroquine for prophylaxis or treatment of SARS-CoV-2 infection" are not yet established.
CDC wi'i yo'o "hoosugo, hokkugo, mala neeɓugo hydroxychloroquine ngam prophylaxis mmala hurgol nyau SARS-CoV-2" jarfakke tawon.
Doctors have said they are using the drug when "there's no other option".
Lekkitoɓe wi'i yo'o ɓe ɗon hokka lekki man to "wala dabare feere".
A Turkish research team in Istanbul is conducting a small study on the use of chloroquine in combination with zinc, vitamin A, vitamin C and vitamin D.
Geeɓe teffol Turkia'en feere ha Istanbul ɗon sallina ekkitol feere do chloroquine be zinc, vitamin A, vitamin C be vitamin D.
Large studies are underway at Duke University and the University of Oxford.
Ekkitolji feere maungel ɗon do lawol ha Duke University be University of Oxford.
NYU Langone Medical School is conducting a trial on the safety and efficacy of preventative use of hydroxychloroquine.
NYU Langone Medical School ɗon waɗa foondol do jam e naffuda hoosugo hydroxychloroquine bana dabare aynol.
Chinese clinical trials in Wuhan and Shenzhen claimed to show favipiravir was "clearly effective".
Foondolji ha suudu lekki Cayna ha Wuhan be Shenzhen wi'i yo'o favipiravir ɗon "naffa masin".
35 patients in Shenzhen tested negative in a median of 4 days, while the length of illness was 11 days in the 45 patients who did not receive it.
Nyauɓe 35 ha Shenzhen larti bana maray nyau ha nder balɗe 4, e juttol nyau man bo'o balɗe 11 ha cakka nyauɓe 45 je hoosay ɗum.
In a study conducted in Wuhan on 240 patients with pneumonia, half were given favipiravir and half received umifenovir.
Ha nder ekkitol feereha Wuhan ha do nyauɓe 240 be pneumonia, reeta maɓɓe hoosi favipiravir be reeta maɓɓe hoosi umifenovir.
The Italian Pharmaceutical Agency reminded the public that the existing evidence in support of the drug is scant and preliminary.
Italian Pharmaceutical Agency matini ummatore yo'o sappinolji do wallende lekki ndu moftay tawon e jarfay.

On 2 April, Germany announced that it would purchase the drug from Japan for its stockpile, and use the military to deliver the drug to university hospitals, where the drug will be used to treat COVID-19 patients.
Ha 2 Aviiril, Jaamani matini yo'o o soddan lekki ha Japan ngam ɗon mofti ha ton, soje'en ngam addugo lekki man ha suuɗi lekki jam'iareji, e lekki man wonan ngam hurgugo nyauɓe COVID-19.

According to the South China Morning Post, Shinzo Abe has made overtures to the Trump administration about purchasing the drug.The drug may be less effective in severe cases of illness where the virus has already multiplied.
Ha South China Morning Post, Shinzo Abe arti ngomna Trump ngam soddugo lekki. Lekki footi wona maray sembe jur ha hurgol nyauɓe je nyau maɓɓe ɗon nyaɗi, e viriis man nufti timmi.
It may not be safe for use by pregnant women or those trying to conceive.
Footi wonatta boɗɗu ha rewɓe be reedu hoosa ndu mala ɓe'en je yiɗi hoosugo reedu.
One study of lopinavir/ritonavir (Kaletra), a combination of the antivirals lopinavir and ritonavir, concluded that "no benefit was observed".
Ekkitol feere do lopinavir/ritonavir (Kaletra), hawtirde lopinavir be ritonavir je ɗon mbarda viriis, wi'i yo'o "wala naffuda je tawama".
The drugs were designed to inhibit HIV from replicating by binding to the protease.
Lekki ndi wurti ngam tuttugo HIV gal nuftugo gal hawtugo be protease.

A team of researchers at the University of Colorado are trying to modify the drugs to find a compound that will bind with the protease of SARS-CoV-2.There are criticisms within the scientific community about directing resources to repurposing drugs specifically developed for HIV/AIDS.

Geeɓe teffooɓe ha University of Colorado yiɗi saanjugo lekki ngam heɓɓugo hawtirde je footi hawta be protease SARS-CoV. Wodi lasbinolji ha kunde ummatore teffooɓe ngam ɗowugo kujeji ngam laritugo lekki je wurtini ngam HIV/AIDS.
The WHO included lopinavir/ritonavir in the international Solidarity trial.
WHO watti lopinavir/ritonavir ha nder foondol lesdi feere-feere Solidarity .

Remdesivir was created and developed by Gilead Sciences as a treatment for Ebola virus disease and Marburg virus infections . Gilead Sciences subsequently discovered that Remdesivir had antiviral activity in vitro against multiple filo-, pneumo-, paramyxo-, and corona- viruses .

Remdesivir waɗɗotto e wurtinama gal Gilead Sciences bana hurgol nyau viriis Ebola be nyauji viriis Marburg. Gilead Sciences tawi fahin bo'o Remdesivir ɗon mari kuɗe je ɗon mbarda viriis in vitro do viriisji jur bana filo-, pneumo-, paramyxo-, be korona.
One issue with antiviral treatment is the development of resistance through mutations that can lead to more severe disease and transmission.
Larula gooto ngam hurgol viriis woni neeɓugo gal saanjolji, ko footi yara ha nyau je ɓuri nyaɗugo be sallinol.

Some early pretrial studies suggest remdesivir may have a high genetic barrier to resistance.There are several clinical trials underway, including two conducted by Cleveland University Hospitals; one for people with moderate illness and another for those with more severe illness.

Ekkitolji feere je fuɗɗi hiddeko foondol ɗon wi'a yo'o remdesivir footi mara keleewol gene ngam neeɓugo. Wodi foondolji ha suudu lekki je ɗon salla jonta, bana ɗiɗi je ɗon fadi gal Cleveland University Hospitals; gooto ngam yimɓe be nyau deydey be feere ngam ɓe'en je ɗon mari nyau je ɓuri nyaɗugo.

There are three ongoing clinical trials of intravenous vitamin C for people who are hospitalized and severely ill with COVID-19; two placebo controlled (China, Canada) and one with no control (Italy).

Wodi foondolji ha suudu lekki tati je vitamin C je sallan nder lawol iyam ha yimɓe je ɗon wondi ha suudu lekki e ɗon mari COVID-19 je nyaɗungel; placebo je ɗon ayni ɗiɗi (Cayna, Kanada) be gooto je wala aynugo (Italy).
New York State began trials for the antibiotic azithromycin on 24 March 2020.
New York State fuɗɗi foondolji ngam antibiotik azithromycin ha 24 Maars 2020.

Japan's National Center for Global Health and Medicine (NCGM) is planning a clinical trial for Teijin's Alvesco (ciclesonide), an inhaled corticosteroid for asthma, for the treatment of pre-symptomatic patients infected with the novel coronavirus.

Japan's National Center for Global Health and Medicine (NCGM) ɗon waɗa jaahargal do foondolji ha suudu lekki ngam Teijin's Alvesco (ciclesonide), corticosteroid je mustugo ngam nyau dule, ngam hurgol nyauɓe je maray mandolji nyau tawon je raɓɓi koronaviriis keese.

A form of angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, a Phase II trial is underway with 200 patients to be recruited from severe, hospitalized cases in Denmark, Germany, and Austria to determine the effectiveness of the treatment.

Irin angiotensin-converting enzyme 2, foondol Yaɓɓorde II ɗon do sallugo be nyauɓe 200 je ɓe suɓɓan no ha cakka ɓe'en je nyau man nyaɗi masin, wondi ha suudu lekki ha Denmark, Jaamani, be Ostriya ngam fammugo naffuda hurgol.

Researchers from the Montreal Heart Institute in Canada are currently studying the role of colchicine in reducing inflammation and pulmonary complications in patients suffering from mild symptoms of COVID-19.
Teffooɓe ha Montreal Heart Institute ha Kanada ɗon jaanga kugal colchicine ngam ustugo huudure be nyaji fuffu ha nyauɓe je ɗon mari mandolji COVID-19 deydey.
The study, named COLCORONA, is recruiting 6000 adults aged 40 and over who were diagnosed with COVID-19 and experience mild symptoms not requiring hospitalization.
Ekkitol, ewnotto COLCORONA, ɗon hoosa mauɓe 6000 je mari duɓɓi mala ɓuri je tawotto mari nyau COVID-19 e mari mandolji je maray haaje yahugo ha suudu lekki.
Women who are pregnant or breastfeeding or who do not have an effective contraceptive method are not eligible.
Rewɓe je ɗon be reedu mala je ɗon musina mala mo je maray dabare siwtugo footay hoosa.
Several anticoagulants are being tested in Italy.
Anticoagulantji jur ɗon do lartol ha Italy.
Low-molecular-weight heparin is being widely used to treat patients, prompting the Italian Medicines Agency to publish guidelines on its use.
Heparin je ɗon mari molecule je ɗon lessi ɗon waagare nder hurgol nyauɓe, ko waɗi Italian Medecine Agency wurtina dabareji ngam huwugo be man.
A multicenter study on 300 patients researching the use of enoxaparin sodium at prophylaxis and therapeutic dosages was announced in Italy on April 14.
Wakkere ekkitol feere do nyauɓe 300 je ɗon do teffugo kugal enoxaparin sodium ha prophylaxis be dabare hoosugo matinama ha italy ha 14 Aviiril.

Since SARS-CoV-2 is a virus, considerable scientific attention has been focused on repurposing approved anti-viral drugs that were developed for prior outbreaks such as MERS, SARS, and West Nile virus.
Nde SARS-CoV-2 lati viriis, hakkika aandal wondi ngam laritugo lekki je mbardatta viriis je wangi hiddeko nyauji bana MERS, SARS, be viriis West Nile.
Ribavirin: ribavirin was recommended for COVID-19 treatment according to Chinese 7th edition guidelines
Ribavirin: ribavirin feelama ngam hurgol COVID-19 bana limtol batakkewol sappinol 7 Cayna
Umifenovir: umifenovir was recommended for COVID-19 treatment according to Chinese 7th edition guidelines
Umifenovir: umifenovir feelama ngam hurgol COVID-19 bana limtol batakkewol sappinol 7 Cayna
Some antibiotics that have been identified as potentially repurposable as COVID-19 treatments:
Antibiotikji feere je ɗon maandi bana footi larita ndu bana dabare hurgol COVID-19:
Tocilizumab (Anti-IL-6 receptor): Approved by China.
Tocilizumab (Anti-IL-6 receptor): Cayna jaɓɓi.
Also trials in Italy and China. and see Tocilizumab#COVID-19.
Fahin bo'o foondolji ha Italy be Cayna. e lare Tocilizumab#COVID-19.

It is unclear yet whether conditions arising during pregnancy including diabetes, cardiac failure, hypercoagulability or hypertension might represent additional risk factors for pregnant people as they do for nonpregnant people.From the limited data available, vertical transmission during the third trimester probably does not occur, or only occurs very rarely.

Laɓɓay ha jonta to larulaji je ummikki ha wakati reedu larni nyau sukar, nyau ɓernde, iyam je ɗon ɗacca law mala illam iyam be sembe footi wona sababu je ɗon ɓesda nyau ha rewɓe je ɗon be reedu. Ngam matinolji je wonay jur, sallinol gal do ha ta'irde tataɓool footi wondatta, mala ɗon yotta ndego-ndego.
There is no data yet on early pregnancy.
Wala matinolji ha jonta do reedu je yotti law.
Little evidence exists to permit any solid conclusions about the nature of COVID-19 infection in pregnancy.
Sappinolji pamarron wondi ngam jabbuyeji do nyau COVID-19 ha rewɓe be reedu.

A case series of 43 women from New York who tested positive for COVID-19 showed similar patterns to non-pregnant adults: 86% had mild disease, 9.3% had severe disease and 4.7% developed critical disease.

Wodi rewɓe 43 ha New York je larti bana mari nyau COVID-19 sappini irin mandolji be mauɓe je wonday be reedu: 86% ɗon mari nyau je ɗon deydey, 9.3 ɗon no mari nyau je nyaɗum be 4.7 je mari nyau je ɓuri nyaɗugo.
Fetal distress was reported in two.
Ha kunde maɓɓ ɗiɗi mari no larula be ɓingel.
None of the women developed severe COVID-19 pneumonia or died.
Wala goɗɗo ha cakka rewɓe ndu mari pneumonia COVID-19 je ɗon nyaɗi mala mayi.
All of them had live birth pregnancies and no severe neonatal asphyxia was observed.
Fu maɓɓe mari no reedu ɓesni fu e wala mo je hollini asphyxia ɓingel keese.

The samples of breast milk, amniotic fluid, cord blood and neonatal throat swab were tested for SARS-CoV-2, and all results were negative.In another study on 15 pregnant women, majority of the patients presented with fever and cough, while laboratory tests yielded lymphocytopenia in 12 patients.

Leekuji kossam, ndiyam reedu, iyam jabburu, be leeku tuɗe ɓingel danyinki lartotto ngam SARS-CoV-2, e sappinolji fu holli wala nyau. Ha nder ekkitol feere rewɓe be reedu 15, ɓurna nyauɓe ɗon no sappina wullol ɓaandu be sondaru, gal wakkere feere bo'o lartolji suudu lartol mari no lymphocytopenia 12.
Computed tomography findings of these patients were consistent with previous reports of non-pregnant patients, consisting of ground-glass opacities at early stage.
Sappinolji ta'irdeji be ordo nyauɓe ndu yahidi be sappinolji nyauɓe je wala reedu je sallingo, be yiɓre bana darugal ha fuɗɗorde man.
Follow-up images after delivery showed no progression of pneumonia.Media reports indicate that over 100 women with COVID-19 might have delivered, and in March 2020, no maternal deaths were reported.
Fotoji laynol ha ɓawo ɓesnugo hollay yahde pneumonia. Batakkeji hubaru matini yo'o ɓuri rewɓe 100 be COVID-19 footi ɓesni, e ha Maars 2020, wala mayde daada je matinama.

Their guidelines thus advise that any pregnant person admitted to hospital with a COVID-19 infection should receive at least 10 days of prophylactic low-molecular-weight heparin after being discharged from the hospital.

Laahalji maɓɓe ɗon feela kadi kala debbo je ɗon mari reedu je nasti ha suudu lekki be nyau COVID-19 sey hokke balɗe 10 ngam heparin je mari molecul prophylactic je lessi ha ɓawo wurtol ha suudu lekki.
There are no data yet concerning the implications of COVID-19 infections for labour.
Wala matinolji je ɗon larni nyau COVID-19 ngam ɓesnugo.

One infant girl born to a mother with COVID-19 had elevated IgM levels two hours after birth, suggesting that she had been infected in utero and supporting the possibility of vertical transmission in some cases.
Woɗi debbo feere je mari COVID-19 ɓesni ɓingel debbo be IgM ɗon wa'i ha ɓawo dayinki, ko ɗon holla yo'o o raɓɓi nyau ndu ha reedu e ɗon sappina bo'o sallinol diga do ha les ha yakke feere.

A small study involving 6 confirmed COVID-19 mothers showed no indication of SARS-COV-19 in their newborns' throats or serum but antibodies were present in neonatal blood sera samples, including IgM in two of the infants.

Ekkitol feere be daadaji 6 je ɗon aandi nyau COVID-19 sappinay mandolji SARS-CoV-19 ha daande mala neebam ɓaandu ɓikkon maɓɓe amma fadooɓe ɓaandu ɗon no ha nder leeku iyam, bana IgM ha cakka ɓikkon ɗiɗi.
This is not usually passed from mother to fetus so further research is required to know whether the virus crossed the placenta or whether placentas of women in the study were damaged or abnormal.
Ndu sallatta tum diga daada ha ɓingel ha reedu sey teffolji tokkita ngam fammugo to viriis ta'itti suudu ɓingel mala suuɗi ɓikkon rewɓe ha nder jaangirde ndu woni no.
Since COVID-19 shows similarities to SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV, it is likely that their effect on pregnancy are similar.
Nde COVID-19 ɗon mari naandolji be SARS-CoV be MERS-CoV, footi sababuji maɓɓe do reedu naanda.
Four of seven had first trimester miscarriage, two of five had fetal growth restriction in the second trimester, and four of five had preterm birth.
Nay nder joowey e ɗiɗi ruffi ha aranool ta'irde, ɗiɗi ha nder joowey mari darnol nder maunugo ɓingel ha nder reedu nder ta'irde ɗiɗaɓool, be danyinki hiddeko wakati man.
None of the newborns were infected with SARS-CoV.
Wala mo je mari nyau SARS-CoV ha kunde ɓikkon je ɓe danyi.
A report of ten cases of MERS- CoV infection in pregnancy in Saudi Arabia showed that the clinical presentation is variable, from mild to severe infection.
Matinol do nyauɓe MERS-CoV ha rewɗɓe be reedu sappo ha Saudi Arabiya sappini yo'o mandolji nyau footi sanja, diga kooyɗum ha nyaɗum.

The outcome was favorable in a majority of the cases, but the infant death rate was 27%.A recent review suggested that COVID-19 appeared to be less lethal to mothers and infants than SARS and MERS but that there may be an increased risk of preterm birth after 28 weeks' gestation.

Sappinol wondi kanduɗum ha ɓurna nyauɓe fu, amma limtol mayde ɗikkon lati 27%. Lartol keese holli yo'o COVID-19 woni bana mari limtol mayde je lessi ha daadiraɓe be ɓikkon do SARS be MERS amma footi sababuji feere do dayinki ha ɓawo asaweji reedu 28.

The World Health Organization and Centers for Disease Control and Prevention of the United States advises pregnant women to do the same things as the general public to avoid infection, such as covering cough, avoid interacting with sick people, cleaning hands with soap and water or sanitizer.

Geeɓe Duniyaru do Jam Ɓaandu be Ɗowirɗeji do Aynol e Lartol Nyau lesɗe America ɗon feela rewɓe be reedu ngaɗa kuje bana ummatore feere ngamm ta be nanga nyau bana suddu hunduko to bana ɗon sonda, ta joɗɗide be nyauɓe, lallugo juɗe be sabulu be ndiyam mala kuje laɓɓinugo.
A survey conducted in Shanghai among pregnant women in different trimesters of pregnancy identified a strong demand for online access to health information and services.
Emmolji feere je sallini ha Shangai ha kunde rewɓe be reedu ha nder ta'irdeji feere-feere ɗon maandi bana ewnandu kanduɗum ngam nastirde do hawo ha matinolji do jam ɓaandu be kuɗe.

People expecting their first baby were more willing to have online consultation and guidance than who had previously given birth.The RCOG and RCM recommend that in-person appointments be deferred by 7 days after the start of symptoms of COVID-19 or 14 days if another person in the household has symptoms.

Yimɓe je ɗon ndeena jippol ɓingel maɓɓe yardi no emmugo feelore gal hawo than ɓe'en je ɓesni timmi. RCOG be RCM ɗon feela yo'o ngidol gite be gite sey wonda ha ɓawo balɗe 7 diga fuɗɗam mandolji nyau COVID-19 mala balɗe 14 to goɗɗo feere ha saare ɗon mari maandolji nyau.
Fever subsequently developed in three asymptomatic patients.
Wullo ɓaandu wangi ha nyauɓe tati je maray mandolji.
One patient who had tested negative subsequently became symptomatic postpartum and tested positive three days after the initial negative test.
Nyauɗo gooto je larti bana maay nyau lati ɗon sappina mandolji nyau postpartum e larti mari nyau balɗe tati ha ɓawo larto je sappini o maray no nyau.

The doctors conducting the screening recommended that in order to reduce infection and allocate PPE, due to high numbers of patients presenting as asymptomatic, universal screening of pregnant patients should be conducted.
Lekkitaɓe je ngaɗatta lartol feeli yo'o ngam ustugo nyau e hokka PPE, ngam limgal nyauɓe je sappinata mondolji nyau, sey waɗa lartol nyauɓe je ɗon be reedu fu.
They also suggest that people with suspected or confirmed COVID-19 should have continuous electronic fetal monitoring.
Fahin, ɓe feeli yo'o yimɓe je bana mari nyau mala mari COVI-19 sey larta wonde ɓinge ha reedu tum be ordoji.
The use of birthing pools is not recommended for suspected or confirmed cases of COVID-19 due to the risk of infection via faeces.
Huwugo be tassawu dayugo nder ndiyam feelakke ha yimɓe je bana mari nyau mala je ɗon aandi mari COVID-19 ngam sababu sallinugo gal buuwe.

In the UK, official recommendations state that precautionary separation of a mother and a healthy baby should not be undertaken lightly and that they should be kept together in the postpartum period where neonatal care is not required.Literature from China recommended separation of infected mothers from babies for 14 days.

Ha Lesɗe Inglisiya, feelore ngomna wi'i yo'o hakkika sendugo daada be ɓingel je maray nyau sey hoosa ndu be boɗɗe e sey wonda ha baabal feere ha wakati postpartum je suklare ngam dayinki wala naffuda. Jaangirde ha Cayna feeli sendugo daadiraɓe je nyauɓe be ɓikkon ha nder balɗe 14.

In the US there is also the recommendation that newborns and mothers should be temporarily separated until transmission-based precautions are discontinued, and that where this is not possible the newborn should be kept 2 metres away from the mother.

Ha Lesɗe America wodi feelore je ɓikkon je ɓa danyi keesum be daadiraɓe sey wonda sendama ha nder wakati seeɗa sey to hakkilo ngam sallinol nyau timmi, e to footay waɗa sey daada wona metaa ɗiɗi be mako.
b'COVID-19 surveillance involves monitoring the spread of the coronavirus disease in order to establish the patterns of disease progression.
Aynol b'COVID-19 larni sankittol nyau koronaviriis ngam wanginugo dabare yahde nyau.
The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends active surveillance, with focus of case finding, testing and contact tracing in all transmission scenarios.
Geeɓe Duniyaru do Jam Ɓaandu (WHO) feeli aynol tum, do teffugo irin nyauɓe, lartol e teffol yimɓe je on ngidi be maɓɓe ha nder sallinolji fu.

COVID-19 surveillance is expected to monitor epidemiological trends, rapidly detect new cases, and based on this information, provide epidemiological information to conduct risk assessment and guide disease preparedness.
Aynol COVID-19 wonan do laritugo yahde nyau ndu, larta nyauɓe keese be laugel, e do matinolji ndu, hokka matinolji do nyau ndu ngam lartugo sababu je yahidatta be man e taska ngam nyau ndu.
Syndromic surveillance is done based on the symptoms of an individual that corresponds to COVID-19.
Aynol nyau wondi do mandolji nyau goɗɗo je ɗon naandi be COVID-19.
As of March 2020, the WHO recommends the following case definitions:
Ha maars 2020, WHO feeli ndu bana ɗon limti ndu:
Probable case : "A suspect case for whom testing for the COVID-19 virus is inconclusive" OR "a suspect case for whom testing could not be performed for any reason".
Footi mara: "Goɗɗo je lartay boɗɗum ha nyau COVID-19" MALA "goɗɗo je footi mari e je lartol footay salla ngam uja feere".
Confirmed case: "A person with laboratory confirmation of COVID-19 infection, irrespective of clinical signs and symptoms".
Aandi mari: "Goɗɗo je larti mari nyau COVID-19, ko to o wala sappinugo mandolji nyau".
Direct physical contact with a probable or confirmed case;
Ngidol ɓaandu be goɗɗo je footi mara mala mari nyau;
Direct care for a patient with probable or confirmed COVID-19 disease without using proper personal protective equipment;
Suklare do nyauɗo je footi mara mala je mari nyau COVID-19 je ɗon aandi bila ɓornugo dabareji fadol ɓaandu;
Other situations as indicated by local risk assessments".WHO recommends reporting of probable and confirmed cases of COVID-19 infection within 48 hours of identification.
Kujeji feere bana ɗon limti gal lartolji sababu". WHO ɗon feela matinugo yimɓe je footi mara mala je ɗon mari nyau COVID-19 ha nder njamɗe 48 maandirɗum.
The countries should report on a case-by-case basis as far as possible, but in case of limitation in resources, aggregate weekly reporting is also possible.
Lesɗe sey matina do goɗɗo do goɗɗo bana ko wowa, amma to footay waɗa ngam dabareji wala, moftugo matinolji ha nder asawere footi waɗa.
Some organizations have created crowdsourced apps for syndromic surveillance, where people can report their symptoms to help researchers map areas with concentration of COVID-19 symptoms.
Geeɓeji feere wangini applikasioji waagare ngam aynol mandolji nyau, je yimɓe footi matina mandolji nyau maɓɓe ngam wallugo teffooɓe maanda wakkereji je mandolji COVID-19 ɗon mofti
Virological surveillance is done by using molecular tests for COVID-19.
Aynol yahde viriis ngaɗotto gal huwidugo be lartol molecul ngam COVID-19.
WHO has published resources for laboratories on how to perform testing for COVID-19.
WHO wurtini kujeji ngam cuuɗi lartol do noy ngaɗugo lartol COVID-19.
In the European Union, laboratory confirmed cases of COVID-19 are reported within 24 hours of identification.
Ha nder Kawtal Lesɗe Erop, yimɓe je lartotto ha suudu lartol e je ɗon mari nyau COVID-19 ɗon matini ha nder njamdi 24.
At least 24 countries have established digital surveillance of their citizens.
Pettum man lesɗe 24 wurtini aynol gal ordoji ha ummatore maɓɓe.
The digital surveillance technologies include apps, location data and electronic tags.
Dabareji aynol gal ordoji larni applikasioji, matinolji do wakkere be kujeji feere.
The Center For Disease Control and Prevention in USA tracks the travel information of individuals using airline passenger data.
Ɗowirɗe Aynol e Lartol Nyau ha Lesɗe America ɗon larta matinolji jaahangal yimɓe gal hoccugo matinolji sallooɓe.
In Hong Kong, authorities are requiring a bracelet and an app for all travellers.
Ha Hong Kong, yimɓe ngomna ɗon emma kuje wattugo ha jungo be applikasion ngam waɗɗooɓe jaahangal fu.
A GPS app is used to track the locations of individuals in South Korea to ensure against quarantine breach, sending alerts to the user and to authorities if people leave designated areas.
Applikasion GPS ɗon walla ngam lartugo wonde yimɓe ha South Korea ngam tato watta goɗɗo ha seera meere, gal neldol mandol ha goɗɗo man be yimɓe ngomna yimɓe wurti wakkere ndu.
In Singapore, individuals have to report their locations with photographic proof.
Ha Singapore, yimɓe sey matina wakkere wonde ma
Thailand is using an app and SIM cards for all travelers to enforce their quarantine.
Thailand ɗon huwa be applikasion be karte SIM ngam waɗɗooɓe jaahangal fu ngam aynol wonde maɓɓe ha seera.
Human rights organizations have criticized some of these measures, asking the governments not to use the pandemic as a cover to introduce invasive digital surveillance.
Geeɓe jarfuji neɗɗo lasbini irin dabareji man feere, gal emmugo ngomna'en to ɓe hoosa nyau duniyaru ndu bana suddol nastinugo dabare aynugo yimɓe gal ordoji.
b'A COVID-19 vaccine is a hypothetical vaccine against coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19).
Baatal b'A COVID-19 lati bana baatal je aandakke boɗɗum ngam nyau koronaviriis 2019 (COVID-19).
Although no vaccine has completed clinical trials, there are multiple attempts in progress to develop such a vaccine.
Ko to wala baatal je timmini foondolji ha suudu lekki, wodi dabareji feere-feere nder yahde ngam wurtinugo irin baatal ndu.
In late February 2020, the World Health Organization (WHO) said it did not expect a vaccine against SARS-CoV-2, the causative virus, to become available in less than 18 months.
Ha Feviriye 2020, Geeɓe Duniyaru do Jam Ɓaandu (WHO) wi'i o tammay baatal SARS-CoV-2, viriis je hokki nyau ndu, wonda hiddeko leebi 18.
Five vaccine candidates were in Phase I safety studies in April.
Baatalji foondol joowey ɗon no do ekkitolji jam Yaɓɓorde I ha Aviiril.
COVID-19 was identified in December 2019.
COVID-19 wangi ha Desambre 2020.
A major outbreak spread around the world in 2020, leading to considerable investment and research activity to develop a vaccine.
Sankittol nyau man ha nder duniyaru salli ha 2020, je waɗi ceede jur nasti e aandooɓe ɗon teffa wurtinol baatal.
Many organizations are using published genomes to develop possible vaccines against SARS-CoV-2.
Geeɓeji jur ɗon huwida be genomeji ngam wurtinugo baatalji nyau SARS-CoV-2.
Stated in April, imperatives of the CEPI initiative for vaccine development are speed, manufacturing capacity, deployment at scale, and global access.
Wurti ha Aviiril, feeloji dabare CEPI ngam wanginugo baatal lati jaawal, dabare tagle, huwidugo ummatore jur, keɓɓal ko moy fu.
In April, CEPI scientists reported that 10 different technology platforms were under research and development during early 2020 to create an effective vaccine against COVID-19.
Ha Aviril, aandooɓe CEPI matini daaldaji dabareji 10 ɗon no nder teffol be wanginnol ha fuɗɗam 2020 ngam wurtinugo baatal je ɗon naffa ngam COVID-19.
Major platform targets advanced into Phase I safety studies include:
Daaldal kanduɗum ɗon nder ekkitolji jam Yaɓɓorde I je ɗon larni:
nucleic acid (DNA and RNA) (Phase I developer and vaccine candidate: Moderna, mRNA-1273)
nucleic acid (DNA be RNA) (wanginoowo Yaɓɓorde I be baatal foondol: Moderna, mRNA-1273)
viral vector (Phase I developer and vaccine candidate: CanSino Biologics, adenovirus type 5 vector)
viriis nyau (wanginowo Yaɓɓorde I be baatal foondol: CanSino Biologics, adenovirus type 5 vector)

As reported by CEPI scientists in April, 115 total vaccine candidates are in early stages of development, with 78 confirmed as active projects (79, according to the Milken Institute), and 37 others announced, but with little public information available (presumed to be in planning or being designed).

Bana ɗon matini gal aandooɓe CEPI ha Aviiril, baatalji foondol hawti fu 115 ɗon do taskugo, be 78 lati bana kuɗe je ɗon yahida (79, ha sappinol Milken Institute), be 37 feere ɗon matini, amma be matinolji ummatore ɗon wondi (je nastan ha nder jaahargal mala ɗon suɓɓi).
A Phase I-II trial conducts preliminary safety and immunogenicity testing, is typically randomized, placebo-controlled, and at multiple sites, while determining more precise, effective doses.
Foondol Yaɓɓorɗe I-II ɗon sallina arandere lartolji jam be immunogenecity, lati bana caacaa, aynotto be placebo, e ha wakkereji ɗuɗɗum, ha yakke maandugo hoosugo ndu be boɗɗe.

Phase III trials typically involve more participants, including a control group, and test effectiveness of the vaccine to prevent the disease, while monitoring for adverse effects at the optimal dose.
Foondolji Yaɓɓorɗe III nastini ummatore jur, be geeɓe aynol, e larita naffuda baatal ngam aynugo nyau, e ngam aynugo sababuji je ɗon yahida be man.
Of 79 vaccine candidates in active development (confirmed as of early April 2020), 74 were not yet in human evaluation (still in "preclinical" research).
Ha cakka baatal foondolji 79 do wurtinol (je ɗon aandin ha fuɗɗam Aviiril 2020), 74 nastay ha nder lartol neɗɗo tawon (ha jonta nder teffol "hiddeko suudu lekki").

Around 24 January 2020 in Australia, the University of Queensland announced that it is investigating the potential of a molecular clamp vaccine that would genetically modify viral proteins in order to stimulate an immune reaction.
Gal 24 Zaanviye 2020 ha Australia, University of Queensland matini yo'o o ɗon no teffa molecule je footi wangina baatal je footi saanja proteinji viriis ndu ngam heɓɓa ɓaandu noota.

Around 24 January 2020 in Canada, the International Vaccine Centre (VIDO-InterVac) at the University of Saskatchewan announced the commencement of work on a vaccine, aiming to start human testing in 2021.
Gal 24 Zaanviye 2020 ha Kanada, International Vaccine Centre (VIDO-InterVac) ha University Saskatchewan matini yo'o fuɗɗam kugal do baatal, je yiɗi sallinugo foondol do neɗɗo ha 2021.
Vaccine development projects were announced at the Chinese Center for Disease Control and Prevention on 26 January 2020, and the University of Hong Kong on 28 January.
Kuɗe wurtinugo baatal matinama ha Ɗowirɗe Aynol e Lartol Nyau Cayna ha 26 Zaanviye 2020, e University of Hong Kong ha 28 Zaanviye.
Around 29 January 2020, Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies, led by Hanneke Schuitemaker, announced that it had begun work on developing a vaccine.
Gal 29 Zaanviye 2020, Janssen Pharmaceutical Companies, je Hanneke Schuitemaker lati arduɗo majuum, wi'i o fuɗɗi huwidugo do baatal ngu.
Janssen is co-developing an oral vaccine with its biotechnology partner, Vaxart.
Janssen ɗon huwida do baatal gal hunduko be bero mako, Vaxart.
On 18 March 2020, Emergent BioSolutions announced a manufacturing partnership with Vaxart to develop the vaccine.
Ha 18 Maars, Emmergent BioSolution matini huwidugo be Vaxart ngam wurtinugo baatal.
On 8 February 2020, the laboratory OncoGen in Romania published a paper on the design of a vaccine with similar technology to the one used for cancer neoantigen vaccination therapy.
Ha 8 Feviriye 2020, suudu lartol OncoGen in Romania wurtini batakkewol feere do dabare wurtinugo baatal be irin teknik je baatal neoantigen hurgol sankara.
On 25 March the head of the research institute announced that they had finalized the synthesis of the vaccine and were beginning the tests.
Ha 25 Maars ɗowuwo geeɓe teffol matini yo'o ɓe timmini lartol baatal e fuɗɗi be lartolji timmi.
On 27 February 2020, a Generex subsidiary company, NuGenerex Immuno-Oncology, announced they were beginning a vaccine project to create an Ii-Key peptide vaccine against COVID-19.
Ha 27 Feviriye 2020, Generex subsidiary company, NuGenerex Immuno-Oncology, matini yo'o ɓe ɗon fuɗɗa kuɗe do teffol baatal ngam wanginugo baatal li-Key peptide ngam nyau COVID-19.
They wanted to produce a vaccine candidate that could be tested in humans "within 90 days."
Ɓe yiɗi wurtinugo baatal foondol je footi en larta do yimɓe "ha nder balɗe 90".
On 5 March 2020, Washington University in St. Louis announced its projects to develop a vaccine.
Ha 5 Maars 2020, Washington University in St. Louis matini kuɗe mako ngam wurtinugo baatal.

On 5 March 2020, the United States Army Medical Research and Materiel Command at Fort Detrick and the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research in Silver Spring, both in western Maryland, announced they were working on a vaccine.

Ha nyalade 5 lewru maars, Arduɗo Geebe Teffol Soje Jam Bandu Lesɗi America ha Fort Detrick be Suudu Jaangirde Teffol Soje Walter Reed ha Silver Spring, ɗiɗi fu ha Marvland je hirnaange, matini yo'o ɓe ɗon huwa ngam wurtinugo baatal.
Around 10 March 2020, Emergent Biosolutions announced that it had teamed with Novavax Inc.
Gal 10 Maars 2020, Emergent Biosolutions matini huwidugo be Novavax Inc.
in the development and manufacture of a vaccine.
ngam dabare wanginugo e wurtinugo baatal.
The partners further announced plans for preclinical testing and a Phase I clinical trial by July 2020.
Bero'en mako matini yo'o jaahargal lartol hiddeko suddu lekki be foondol Yaɓɓorde I ha suudu lekki gal Zwiiye 2020.
On 12 March 2020, India's Health Ministry announced they are working with 11 isolates, and that even on a fast track it would take at least around one-and-a-half to two years to develop a vaccine.
Ha 12 Maars 2020, Geeɓe jam ɓaandu India matini yo'o ɓe ɗon huwa be baatalji 11, e ko to yaawi ma footi neeɓa duɓɓi be reeta mala duɓɓi ɗiɗi ngam wurtinugo baatal.
On 12 March 2020, Medicago, a biotechnology company in Quebec City, Quebec, reported development of a coronavirus-like particle under partial funding from the Canadian Institutes for Health Research.
Ha 12 Maars 2020, Medicago, biotechnology company ha Quebec City, Quebec, matini kugal do wurtinugo kuje feere je ɗon naandi koronaviriis je Canadian Institutes for Health Research hokki ceede seeɗa.
The vaccine candidate is in laboratory research, with human testing planned for July or August 2020.
Baatal foondol ɗon ha nder suudu teffol, be lartolji do yimɓe ɗon hasdi ngam Zwiiye mala Uut 2020.

Earlier that week, The Guardian reported that the US President Donald Trump had offered CureVac "'large sums of money' for exclusive access to a Covid-19 vaccine", against which the German government protested.
Ha fuɗɗam asawere ndu, The Guardian matini yo'o Jagorɗo Lesɗe America Donald Trump hokki ha CureVac "ceede ɗuɗɗum ngam wurtinugo baatal COVID-19", je ngomna Jaamani yarday sam.
On 17 March 2020, American pharmaceutical company Pfizer announced a partnership with German company BioNTech to jointly develop a mRNA-based vaccine.
Ha 17 Maars 2020, American pharmaceutical company Pfizer matini huwidugo be German company BioNTech ngam wurtinugo baatal mRNA.
mRNA-based vaccine candidate BNT162, currently in pre-clinical testing with clinical trials expected to begin in April 2020.
Baatal foondol mRNA BNT162, jonta ha nder lartol hidekko suddu lekki be foondolji je hasdi wurtugo ha fuɗɗam Aviiril 2020.

In Italy on 17 March 2020, Takis Biotech, an Italian biotech company announced they will have pre-clinical testing results in April 2020 and their final vaccine candidate could begin human testing by fall.

Ha Italy ha 17 Maars 2020, Takis Biotech, biotech company Italy matini yo'o ɓe maran sappinolji lartol hiddeko suudu lekki ha Aviiril 2020 e baatal foondol je ragare footi fuɗɗa hiddeko timminol hittande nde.

In France on 19 March 2020, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) announced a US$4.9 million investment in a COVID-19 vaccine research consortium involving the Institut Pasteur, Themis Bioscience (Vienna, Austria), and the University of Pittsburgh, bringing CEPI's total investment in COVID-19 vaccine development to US$29 million.

Ha Faransa ha 19 Maars 2020, Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (CEPI) matini wurtinugo milionji US$4.9 ngam teffol do baatal COVID-19 be geeɓe bana Institut Pasteur, Themis Bioscience (Vienna, Austria), be University of Pittsburgh, ko ɗon hawti moftol ceede CEPI ngam wanginugo baatal COVID-19 ha milionji US$29.
CEPI's other investment partners for COVID-19 vaccine development are Moderna, Curevac, Inovio, Novavax, the University of Hong Kong, the University of Oxford, and the University of Queensland.
Geeji feere je CEPI ɗon huwida be maɓɓe ngam wurtinol baatal nyau COVID-19 lati Moderna, Curevac, Inovio, Novavax, University of Hong Kong, University of Oxford, be University of Queensland.
On 20 March 2020, Russian health officials announced that scientists have begun animal testing of six different vaccine candidates.
Ha 20 Maars 2020, yimɓe ngomna Russiya matini yo'o aandooɓe fuɗɗi lartolji do daabaji be baatalji foondol joowey go'o.
Imperial College London researchers announced on 20 March 2020 that they are developing a self-amplifying RNA vaccine for COVID-19.
Teffooɓe Imperial College London researchers matini ha 20 Maars 2020 yo'o ɓe ɗn no waɗa dabare wurtinugo baatal NRA je ɗon yajja feere maɗa ngam COVID-19.
The vaccine candidate was developed within 14 days of receiving the sequence from China.
Ko footi wona baatal ndu huwidotto ha nder balɗe 14 diga jaɓɓugo kuje man ha Cayna.

In late March, the Canadian government announced C$275 million in funding for 96 research projects on medical countermeasures against COVID-19, including numerous vaccine candidates at Canadian companies and universities, such as the Medicago and University of Saskatchewan initiatives.

Ha ragare Maars, ngomna Kanada matini wurtinugo milionji C$275 bana wallende kuɗe teffol 96 ngam dabareji jam ɓaandu ngam COVID-19, be baatalji foondol jur ha nder geeɓeji be jam'iareji Kanadiya'en bana dabareji Medicago and University of Saskatchewan.

Around the same time, the Canadian government announced C$192 million specifically for developing a COVID-19 vaccine, with plans to establish a national "vaccine bank" of several new vaccines that could be used if another coronavirus outbreak occurs.

Ha wakati ndu, ngomna Kanada matini wurtinugo milionji C$192 ngam wanginugo baatal COVID-19, be jaahargalji mahugo "siggorde baatalji" ngam baatalji keese ɗuɗɗum je footi naffa to nyau koronaviriis feere wangi.

On 2 April 2020, researchers at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine reported on testing of PittCoVacc, a possible COVID-19 vaccine in mice, stating that "MNA delivered SARS-CoV-2 S1 subunit vaccines elicited potent antigen-specific antibody responses [in the mice] that were evident beginning 2 weeks after immunization."

Ha 2 Aviiril 2020, teffooɓe ha University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine matini ngam lartugo PittCoVacc, baatal COVID-19 ha doomɓi, gal wi'ugo yo'o "MNA wurtini geeɓe baatalji SARS-CoV-2 S1 je ɗon tutta fadooɓe ɓaandu je ɗon mari antigene je ɗon mari semɓe [ha nder doomɓi] je fuɗɗan asaweji 2 ha ɓawo fadol."
In Canada on 16 April 2020, the University of Waterloo School of Pharmacy announced design of a DNA-based vaccine candidate as a possible nasal spray.
Ha Kanada ha 16 Aviril 2020, Jam'iare Waterloo School of Pharmacy matini sappinol DNA ko footi wona baatal je lati bana lekki fuffugo ha nder kine.

Using bacteriophages, the DNA will be designed to replicate inside human bacteria to produce harmless virus-like particles, which may stimulate the immune system to produce antibodies against the SARS-CoV-2 virus.

Huwugo be bacteriophageji, DNA naffan ngam nuftugo ha nder bakteriyaji neɗɗo ngam wurtinugo coolaaje je naandi viriis je wala nyaɗugo, je footi sembintina dabare fadol ɓaandu ngam wurtinugo fadooɓe ɓaandu ngam viriis SARS-CoV-2.

In March 2020, the US government, industry, and three universities pooled resources to access supercomputers from IBM, combined with cloud computing resources from Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Amazon, Microsoft, and Google.

Ha Maars 2020, ngomna Lesɗe America, suudu tagle, be jam'iareji hawti sembe maɓɓe ngam nastugo ha nder ordoji nyaɗum gal IBM, hawti be dabareji huwidol do hawo Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Amazon, Microsoft, be Google.
Some vaccines have heterologous effects, also called non-specific effects.
Baatalji feere ɗon mari sababuji feere, e ewnotto bo'o sababuji je ɗon saanja.
That means they can have benefits beyond the disease they prevent.
Bana wi'ugo ɓe footi mara ribaji ha gaɗɗa nyau je ɗon ayna.
A further randomized trial in Australia is seeking to enrol 4,170 healthcare workers.
Foondol feere ha Australia ɗon teffa nastinugo huwooɓe jam ɓaandu 4170.
It is possible vaccines in development will not be safe or effective.
Footi bo'o baatalji je do wurtugo footi wonatta jam mala mara naffuda.

Early research to assess vaccine efficacy using COVID-19-specific animal models, such as ACE2-transgenic mice, other laboratory animals, and non-human primates, indicate a need for biosafety-level 3 containment measures for handling live viruses, and international coordination to ensure standardized safety procedures.

Teffolji arandere ngam lartugo naffitirki baatal gal hoosugo irin COVID-19 je yahidan be daabaji bana doombi ACE2-transgenic., daabaji suudu lartolji feere, be wandu'en je nastay nder asngol neɗɗo, sappina haaje ngam dabareji darnugo biosafety-level 3 ngam memmugo viriisji je ɗon nyeeɗa, be fadol duniyaru ngam hollugo dabareji jam je ɗon aandi.
Vaccines against SARS and MERS have been tested in non-human animal models.
Baatalji ngam SARS be MERS lartama ha nder naandolji je wonay goɗɗo.
As of 2020, there is no cure or protective vaccine for SARS that has been shown to be both safe and effective in humans.
Ha 2020, wala hurgol mala baatal aynugo ngam SARS je sappinama ɗon jam e naffan neɗɗo.

According to research papers published in 2005 and 2006, the identification and development of novel vaccines and medicines to treat SARS was a priority for governments and public health agencies around the world.There is also no proven vaccine against MERS.

Bana sappinol batakkeji teffoln2005 be 2006, maandirɗum be wanginol baataji keese be lekki hurgol SARS lati aranool nummol ngomna'en be geeɓeji jam ɓaandu ummatore ha nder lesdi. Fahin, wala baatal je ɗon aandin ngam MERS.
When MERS became prevalent, it was believed that existing SARS research may provide a useful template for developing vaccines and therapeutics against a MERS-CoV infection.
Ha wakati je MERS wangi, yimɓe tammi yo'o teffolji do SARS footi dabare feere ngam wurtinugo baatalji mala lekki nyau MERS-CoV.

As of March 2020, there was one (DNA based) MERS vaccine which completed phase I clinical trials in humans, and three others in progress, all of which are viral-vectored vaccines, two adenoviral-vectored (ChAdOx1-MERS, BVRS-GamVac), and one MVA-vectored (MVA-MERS-S).

Ha 20 Maars 2020, wodi no baatal MERS (je wondi do DNA) je timmini foondolji yaɓɓorde I ha suudu lekki, be feere en tati, je fu woni baatalji viriis, adenoviriis, (ChAdOx1-MERS, BVRS-GamVac), be MVA-vectored (MVA-MERS-S) woore.
Social media posts have promoted a conspiracy theory claiming the virus behind COVID-19 was known and that a vaccine was already available.
Sappinolji bindi ha hubaru ummatore wurtini ngewte dabare gal wi'ugo viriis je ɗon wondi ha ɓawo COVID-19 ɗon no aandi e baatal man ɗon timmi.
The patents cited by various social media posts reference existing patents for genetic sequences and vaccines for other strains of coronavirus such as the SARS coronavirus.
Aandinolji je ɗon limti ha do daaldal ummatore ɗon lorta ha aandinolji je ɗon no wondi aran ngam ta'irde geneji ngam asli coronaviriis feere bana koronaviriis SARS.
b'Coronaviruses are a group of related viruses that cause diseases in mammals and birds.
Koronaviriisji b' lati geeɓe irin viriisji je ɗon hokka nyauji ha daabaje be cooli.
In humans, coronaviruses cause respiratory tract infections that can range from mild to lethal.
Ha nder nder neɗɗo, koronaviriis ɗon hokka nyau lawol pofɗe je footi umma diga seeɗa ha mayde.
Mild illnesses include some cases of the common cold (which has other possible causes, predominantly rhinoviruses), while more lethal varieties can cause SARS, MERS, and COVID-19.
Nyauji je nyaɗay jur larni nyau bana ndamba (je footi mara ujaji feere, ɓurna fu rhinoviriisji), ha wakati feere asli feere footi hokka SARS, MERS, BE COVID-19.
Symptoms in other species vary: in chickens, they cause an upper respiratory tract disease, while in cows and pigs they cause diarrhea.
Mandolji ha nder daabaji feere ɗon saanja: ha goortoɗe, ɓe ɗon hokka nyau lawol pofɗe dow, ha na'i be gaduji bo'o ɗon hokka caarol.
There are yet to be vaccines or antiviral drugs to prevent or treat human coronavirus infections.
Wala baatal mala lekki mbarugo virisji ngam aynugo mala hurgugo neɗɗo ngam nyau koronaviriis.
Coronaviruses constitute the subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, in the family Coronaviridae, order Nidovirales, and realm Riboviria.
Koroonaviriis ɗon woni ha asngol Orthocoronavirinae, geeɓe Coronaviridae, caalaje Nidovirales, e lamorde Riboviria.
They are enveloped viruses with a positive-sense single-stranded RNA genome and a nucleocapsid of helical symmetry.
Be lati viriisji je ɗon suddi genome je ɗon mari RNA be kosngal gooto be nucleocapsid be ɓaandu yirlama.
The genome size of coronaviruses ranges from approximately 26 to 32 kilobases, one of the largest among RNA viruses.
Maunugo genome koronaviriis ɗon fuɗɗa diga kilobaseji 26 ha 32, gooto ha cakka viriisji RNA je ɓuri yajjugo.
They have characteristic club-shaped spikes that project from their surface, which in electron micrographs create an image reminiscent of the solar corona from which their name derives.
Ɓe ɗon mari bana gi'e ha do do ɓaandu maɓɓe, je to wati nder electon micrographji ɗon waɗa bana naandi foto naange je ɗon jayna ko waɗi inde maɓɓe.
Coronaviruses were first discovered in the 1930s when an acute respiratory infection of domesticated chickens was shown to be caused by infectious bronchitis virus (IBV).
Koronaviriisji tawotto aranool gal 1930 ha wakati je ɓe tawi nyau pofde ha nder goortoɗe saare bana wangi gal viriis bronchitis je ɗon raɓɓa (IBV).
In the 1940s, two more animal coronaviruses, mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) and transmissible gastroenteritis virus (TGEV), were isolated.Human coronaviruses were discovered in the 1960s.
Gal 1940, wodi koronaviriisji daabaji feere, viriis hengre doombi (MHV) be viriis gartroenteritis je ɗon raɓɓa (TGEV), tawotto. Koronaviriisji neɗɗo tawama ja 1960.
The earliest ones studied were from human patients with the common cold, which were later named human coronavirus 229E and human coronavirus OC43.
Arandere je ɗon jaangini wurti ha nyauɓe je mari no ndamba meere, je ewnotto koronaviriis 229E be koronaviriis neɗɗo OC43.
They were first imaged by Scottish virologist June Almeida at St. Thomas Hospital in London.
Arandere fotoji maɓɓe wurti gal jaanginoowo viriis Scotland June Almeida ha St. Thomas Hospital ha London.
Other human coronaviruses have since been identified, including SARS-CoV in 2003, HCoV NL63 in 2004, HKU1 in 2005, MERS-CoV in 2012, and SARS-CoV-2 in 2019.
Koronaviriis neɗɗo feere mandotto diga nden, bana SARS-CoV ha 2003, HCoV NL63 ha 2004, HKU1 ha 2005, MERS-CoV ha 2012, be SARS-CoV-2 ha 2019.
Most of these have involved serious respiratory tract infections.
Ɓurna fu ɗon memma nyauji lawol pofɗe.
The name was first used in 1968 by an informal group of virologists in the journal Nature to designate the new family of viruses.
Inde man wurti aranool man ha 1968 gal geeɓe jaanginooɓe viriisji je aandakke ha nder batakkewol Nature ngam ewnugo caalaje viriisji keese.

The name refers to the characteristic appearance of virions (the infective form of the virus) by electron microscopy, which have a fringe of large, bulbous surface projections creating an image reminiscent of a crown or of a solar corona.
Inde ndu hoccitti do wondugo ɓiɓe viriisji ndu (viriis man je raɓɓatta) gal electron microskopy, je ɗon mari bana gi'e je fuɗɗi do ɓaandu maɗa je ɓiɓe lekki, je wangi bana naange je ɗon jalɓitta.
This morphology is created by the viral spike peplomers, which are proteins on the surface of the virus.
Ndu woni bana ni ngam gi'e peplomerji viriis, je lati proteinji do ɓaandu viriis ndu.
Coronaviruses are large pleomorphic spherical particles with bulbous surface projections.
Koronaviriisji woni bana ɓiɓe lekki bana gi'e ɗon fuɗɗi do ɓaandu maɓɓe je wurti gal laaral ɓaandu.

The envelope of the virus in electron micrographs appears as a distinct pair of electron dense shells.The viral envelope consists of a lipid bilayer where the membrane (M), envelope (E) and spike (S) structural proteins are anchored.
Laaral viriis ha electron micrographji ɗon lara bana bawo electronji je woni ɗiɗi. Laaral viriis ɗon ɗiɗi e tardi ba ɓeelere je ɗon sigga proteinji laaral (M), Laaral (E) be hoore (S).
The lipid bilayer envelope, membrane proteins, and nucleocapsid protect the virus when it is outside the host cell.
Laaral ɓaandu je ɗon ɗiɗi bana ɓeelere, proteinji laaral, be nucleocapsid ɗon fadda viriis to o wurti ɓaandu suudu siggorde maɗa..
Coronaviruses contain a positive-sense, single-stranded RNA genome.
Koronaviriisji ɗon mari genome je positive, be kosngal RNA gooto.
The genome size for coronaviruses ranges from 26.4 to 31.7 kilobases.
Maunugo genome koronaviriis ɗon fuɗɗa diga kilobaseji 26.4 ha 31.7.
The genome size is one of the largest among RNA viruses.
Maunugo genome woni bana je ɓuri maunugo ha kunde viriisji RNA.
The open reading frames 1a and 1b, which occupy the first two-thirds of the genome, encode the replicase/transcriptase polyprotein.
Jaangugo frameji 1a be 1b je ɗon maɓɓitti, je ɗon hoosa genomeji ɗiɗi do tati, lamba polyprotein replicase/transcriptase.
The replicase/transcriptase polyprotein self cleaves to form nonstructural proteins.The later reading frames encode the four major structural proteins: spike, envelope, membrane, and nucleocapsid.
Polyprotein replicase/transcriptase senda ɓaandu maɓɓe ngam lata proteinji je wala tagle. Kuje jaangirde je warango lamban ɓurna proteinji tagle ngel: hoore, laaral, laaral, be nucleocappsid.
Interspersed between these reading frames are the reading frames for the accessory proteins.
Ta'irde ha kunde jaangirde ndu lati jaangirdeji proteinji feere.
The number of accessory proteins and their function is unique depending on the specific coronavirus.
Limtol proteinji feere be kugal maɓɓe lati feerejo be irin koronaviriis.
Infection begins when the viral spike (S) glycoprotein attaches to its complementary host cell receptor.
Raɓɓende ɗo fuɗɗa to glycoprotein hooer (S) hawti be jaɓɓowo cell maɗa je feere ndu.
After attachment, a protease of the host cell cleaves and activates the receptor-attached spike protein.
Ha ɓawo hawtirol, protease cell jaɓɓowo ɗon ta'a e ummina protein hoore je ɗon woni.

Depending on the host cell protease available, cleavage and activation allows the virus to enter the host cell by endocytosis or direct fusion of the viral envelop with the host membrane.On entry into the host cell, the virus particle is uncoated, and its genome enters the cell cytoplasm.

Do protease cell jaɓɓowo je ɗon woni, ta'irde be umminki ɗo waɗa viriis nasta cell jaɓɓowo gal endocytosis mala hawtirde laaral viriis be kuusel ɓaandu jaɓɓowo. Ha wakati nastirde ha nder cell jaɓɓowo, viriis ɓooran, genome maɗa ɗon nasta ha cytoplasm cell.
The host ribosome translates the initial overlapping open reading frame of the virus genome and forms a long polyprotein.
Ko mbiyotto host ribosome ɗon lornita arandere ko goɗɗo footi jaanga ha do gilɗi ndu e ɗon latina ɗum bana poliprotein je juttungel.
The polyprotein has its own proteases which cleave the polyprotein into multiple nonstructural proteins.
Polyprotein ɗon mari proteasji maɗa je ɗon ta'a polyprotein do proteinji je maray ɓaandu.
A number of the nonstructural proteins coalesce to form a multi-protein replicase-transcriptase complex (RTC).
Limgal nonstructural proteinji ɗon hawta ngam wurtinugo multi-protein replicase-transcriptase complex (RTC).
The main replicase-transcriptase protein is the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp).
Aranool protein replicase-transcriptase lati RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp).
It is directly involved in the replication and transcription of RNA from an RNA strand.
Larni ha nder nuftol e jaangirde RNA ha kosɗe RNA.
The other nonstructural proteins in the complex assist in the replication and transcription process.
Proteinji feere je maray ɓaandu ha nder kuje wallan nder nuftol e laahal jaangirde.

The exoribonuclease nonstructural protein, for instance, provides extra fidelity to replication by providing a proofreading function which the RNA-dependent RNA polymerase lacks.One of the main functions of the complex is to replicate the viral genome.
Protein exoribonuclease nonstructural, bana sappinol, ɗon hokka amana ha nuftol gal hokkugo dabare jaangirde je RNA polymerase RNA woda. Gooto ha cakka kuɗe maɓɓe arandere woni nuftugo genome viriis.
RdRp directly mediates the synthesis of negative-sense genomic RNA from the positive-sense genomic RNA.
RdRp sendan lartol negative-sense genomic RNA diga positive-sense genomic RNA.
This is followed by the replication of positive-sense genomic RNA from the negative-sense genomic RNA.
Ndu ɗon tokkitiri be nuftol positive-sense genomic RNA ha negative-sense genomic RNA.
The other important function of the complex is to transcribe the viral genome.
Kugal kanduɗum kuje ndu woni jaangugo genome viriis.
RdRp directly mediates the synthesis of negative-sense subgenomic RNA molecules from the positive-sense genomic RNA.
RdRp ɗon hawta lartol negative-sense subgenomic RNA moleculeji ha positive-sense genomic RNA.
This is followed by the transcription of these negative-sense subgenomic RNA molecules to their corresponding positive-sense mRNAs.
Ndu ɗon tokkiti be irin negative-sense subgenomic RNA moleculeji ha positive-sense mRNAs je ɗon naandi.
The replicated positive-sense genomic RNA becomes the genome of the progeny viruses.
Positive-sense genomic RNA je nuftama latan genome viriis je waratta.
The mRNAs are gene transcripts of the last third of the virus genome after the initial overlapping reading frame.
mRNAs lati jaangirde gene gooto nder tati ragare genome viriis ha ɓawo aranol jaangirde ndu.
These mRNAs are translated by the host's ribosomes into the structural proteins and a number of accessory proteins.
mRNAs ndu lornama gal jaɓɓowo ribosomeji ha nder structural proteinji be proteinji feere.
RNA translation occurs inside the endoplasmic reticulum.
lornugo RNA ɗon salla nder retikulum endoplasmic.
The viral structural proteins S, E, and M move along the secretory pathway into the Golgi intermediate compartment.
Viral structural proteins S, E, be M ɗon yahda gal lawol tuttol ha nder suudu Golgi je cakkare.
There, the M proteins direct most protein-protein interactions required for assembly of viruses following its binding to the nucleocapsid.
Ha ton, M proteinji M ɗon nelda kuɗe protein-protein mari haaje mofturde viriisji gal tokkitol hawtirde maɓɓe be nucleocapsid.
Progeny viruses are then released from the host cell by exocytosis through secretory vesicles.
Viriisji asngol yoffotto ha host cell gal exocytosis gal lawol wurtol tuttol.
The interaction of the coronavirus spike protein with its complement host cell receptor is central in determining the tissue tropism, infectivity, and species range of the virus.
Kuɗe koronaviriis spike protein be host cell receptor kanduɗum nder fammugo tissue tropism, raɓɓ, asngol e caalage viriis.
The SARS coronavirus, for example, infects human cells by attaching to the angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptor.
Koronaviriis SARS, bana sappinol, ɗon memma cellji gal hawtugo be angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) receptor.
The scientific name for coronavirus is Orthocoronavirinae or Coronavirinae.
Inde jaangirde koronaviriis woni Orthocoronavirinae mala Coronavirinae.
Coronaviruses belong to the family of Coronaviridae, order Nidovirales, and realm Riboviria.
Koronaviriis ɗon nasta nder geeɓe Coronaviridae, tokkitol Nidovirales, be asli Riboviria.
Genus Betacoronavirus; type species: Murine coronavirus
Inde Betacoronavirus; irin geeɓe: Murine coronavirus

Species: Betacoronavirus 1 (Bovine Coronavirus, Human coronavirus OC43), Human coronavirus HKU1, Murine coronavirus, Pipistrellus bat coronavirus HKU5, Rousettus bat coronavirus HKU9, Severe acute respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus (SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2), Tylonycteris bat coronavirus HKU4, Middle East respiratory syndrome-related coronavirus, Hedgehog coronavirus 1 (EriCoV)

Asli: Betacoronavirus 1 (Koronaviriis Na'i, Koronaviriis Neɗɗo OC43), Neɗɗo HKU1, Murine koronaviriis, Pipistrellus koronaviriis bilwili HKU5, Rousettus koronaviriis bilwili HKU9, koronaviriis je ɗon hokka nyau pofɗe nyaɗum (SARS-CoV, SARS-CoV-2), Tylonycteris koronaviriis bilwili HKU4, koronaviriis je ɗon hokka nyau je saɗirma nder pofɗe Cakkare Funaange, koronaviriis 1 camnagel (EriCoV)
Species: Beluga whale coronavirus SW1, Infectious bronchitis virus
Asli: Beluga whale koronaviriiss SW1, viriis Infectious bronchitis

The most recent common ancestor (MRCA) of all coronaviruses is estimated to have existed as recently as 8000 BCE, although some models place the common ancestor as far back as 55 million years or more, implying long term coevolution with bat and avian species.

Maama asngol koronaviriis je wangi neeɓay (MRCA) waɗi bana yahan gal 8000 BCE, ko to irin feere ɗon yara maama je ɓurna fu gal duɓɓi milionji 55 mala ɓuri, je yiɗi sappinugo yahidottol juttungel be bilwili be cooli.

The most recent common ancestor of the alphacoronavirus line has been placed at about 2400 BCE, the betacoronavirus line at 3300 BCE, the gammacoronavirus line at 2800 BCE, and the deltacoronavirus line at about 3000 BCE.
Maama asngol alphakoronaviriis je wangi neeɓay ndu wonan gal 2400 BCE, asngol betakoronaviriis ha 3300 BCE, asngol gammakoronaviriis ha 2800 BCE, be asngol ddeltakoronaviriis gal 3000 BCE.
The large number of host bat and avian species, and their global range, has enabled extensive evolution and dissemination of coronaviruses.Many human coronavirus have their origin in bats.
Limtol geeɓeji bilwili siggorde be cooli, be hawtirde maɓɓe, sappini yahde be sankittol koronaviriisji je juttungel. Koronaviriis neɗɗo ɗuɗɗum ummi ha bilwili.
More recently, alpaca coronavirus and human coronavirus 229E diverged sometime before 1960.
Neeɓay ɗo, koronaviriis alpaka be koronaviriis neɗɗo 229E waylitti ha wakati feere hiddeko 1960.
MERS-CoV emerged in humans from bats through the intermediate host of camels.
MERS-CoV wangi ha neɗɗo diga bilwili be suudu cakkare mako ngeeloba.
MERS-CoV, although related to several bat coronavirus species, appears to have diverged from these several centuries ago.
MERS-CoV, ko to larni asli koronaviriis bilwili jur ma, bana waylitti ha maɓɓe diga ujineje ɗuɗum.
The most closely related bat coronavirus and SARS-CoV diverged in 1986.
Koronaviriis bilwili je ɓuri ɓadugo be SARS-CoV waylitti ha 1986.
A possible path of evolution, of SARS coronavirus and keen bat coronaviruses, suggests that SARS related coronaviruses coevolved in bats for a long time.
Lawol yahde ndu koronaviriis SARS be koronaviriisji bilwili, ɗon sappina yo'o koronaviriisji SARS yahidi no ha nder bilwili diga ɓoyma.
In the 1790s, equine coronavirus diverged from the bovine coronavirus after a cross-species jump.
Ha 1790, koronaviriis pucci waylitti diga koronaviriis na'i ha ɓawo hawtirde maɓɓe.
Later in the 1890s, human coronavirus OC43 diverged from bovine coronavirus after another cross-species spillover event.
Ha ɓawo man gal 1890, koronaviriis neɗɗo OC43 waylitti diga koronaviriis na'i ha ɓawo hawtirde maɓɓe.

It is speculated that the flu pandemic of 1890 may have been caused by this spillover event, and not by the influenza virus, because of the related timing, neurological symptoms, and unknown causative agent of the pandemic.

Yimɓe tammi yo'o nyau ndamba je 1890 je memmei duniyaru fu footi wangi gal kuje feere, amma na gal viriis ndamba, ngam wakati man, mandolji neuronji, be gilɗi je footi wangini nyau duniyaru ndu je aandakke.
Human coronavirus OC43 besides causing respiratory infections is also suspected of playing a role in neurological diseases.
Koronaviriis neɗɗo OC43 do hokkugo nyauji pofɗe woni bana ɗon fiija nder sallinugo nyauji neuronji.
In the 1950s, the human coronavirus OC43 began to diverge into its present genotypes.
Gal 1950, koronaviriis OC43 fuɗɗi waylittugo ha yotta genotypeji ndu.
Phylogentically, mouse hepatitis virus (Murine coronavirus), which infects the mouse's liver and the central nervous system, is related to human coronavirus OC43 and bovine coronavirus.
Bana lartol wangirde maɗa, viriis hengre doombi (koronaviriis Murine), je ɗon memma hengre doomru be kugal ngandi, ɗon hawti be koronaviriis neɗɗo OC43 be koronaviriis na'i.
Human coronavirus HKU1, like the aforementioned viruses, also has its origins in rodents.
Koronaviriis neɗɗo HKU1, bana viriisji je en limti ha do ndu, wangi gal yaamooɓe.
Coronaviruses vary significantly in risk factor.
Koronaviriis ɗon saanja ɗuɗɗum do ko ɗon wangina ɗum.
Some can kill more than 30% of those infected, such as MERS-CoV, and some are relatively harmless, such as the common cold.
Feere footi mbara ɓuran 30 nder 100 ha cakka nyauɓe, bana MERS-CoV, e feere lati bana nyaɗay, bana ndamba tan.
Coronaviruses can cause colds with major symptoms, such as fever, and a sore throat from swollen adenoids.
Koronaviriisji footi hokka ndamba be ɓurna mandolji bana wullol baandu, be daande be huudure ngam adenoidji ɗon uppi.
Coronaviruses can cause pneumonia (either direct viral pneumonia or secondary bacterial pneumonia) and bronchitis (either direct viral bronchitis or secondary bacterial bronchitis).
Koronaviriisji footi hokka pneumonia (pneumonia viriis aranool mala pneumonia bakteriyaji ɗiɗaɓool) be bronchitis (bronchitis viriis aranool mala bronchitis bakteriyaji ɗiɗiɓool).

The human coronavirus discovered in 2003, SARS-CoV, which causes severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), has a unique pathogenesis because it causes both upper and lower respiratory tract infections.Six species of human coronaviruses are known, with one species subdivided into two different strains, making seven strains of human coronaviruses altogether.

Koronaviriis neɗɗo je tawama ha 2003, SARS-CoV, je ɗon hokka nyau pofɗe je nyaɗum (SARS), ɗon mari mandol nyau feerejo ngam ɗon raɓɓa lawol pofɗe je do be je les. Asli koronaviriis neɗɗo joowey e go'o ɗon aandin, be asngol gootoo je ɗon sendi nde caalaje ɗiɗi, ko wartiri ndu koronaviriisji neɗɗo joowey e ɗiɗi.
Four of these coronaviruses continually circulate in the human population and produce the generally mild symptoms of the common cold in adults and children worldwide: -OC43, -HKU1, HCoV-229E, -NL63.
Nay ha cakka koronaviriisji ndu ɗon tokkita doggugo ha cakka ummatore e ɓurna fu ɗon wangina mandolji ndamba je nyaɗay ha mauɓe be ɓikkon ha nder duniyaru fu: -OC43, -HKU1, HCoV-229E, -NL63.
Coronaviruses cause about 15% of commons colds.
Koronaviriisji ɗon hokka 15% ndamɗa meere.
The majority of colds are caused by rhinoviruses.
Ndambaji ɓurna fu wangi gal rhinoviriisji.
The four mild coronaviruses have a seasonal incidence occurring in the winter months in temperate climates.
Koronaviriisji nay je nyaɗay sam ɗon mari yahde be wakati e ɗon wanga ha yakke peewol ha wakkereji feere.
There is no preference towards a particular season in tropical climates.
Wala saanjol be wakatiji nde gal tropikji.
Four human coronaviruses produce symptoms that are generally mild:
Koronaviriisji neɗɗo nay ɗon sappina mandolji je ɓurna fu ɗon:
The virus was officially named the SARS coronavirus (SARS-CoV).
Viriis hoosi inde SARS coronaviriis (SARS-CoV).
More than 8,000 people were infected, about ten percent of whom died.
Yimɓe ɓuran 8000 raɓɓi nyau ndu, je sappo nder temere ha cakka maɓɓe mayi.
In September 2012, a new type of coronavirus was identified, initially called Novel Coronavirus 2012, and now officially named Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV).
Ha septambre 2012, wodi koronaviriis keese wangi, aranool man inde man Koronaviriis 2012 Keese, amma jonta hoosi inde koronaviriis Cakkare Funaange je ɗon hokka nyau pofɗe (MERS-CoV)
The World Health Organization issued a global alert soon after.
Geeɓe Duniyaru do Jam Ɓaanɗu daasi hakkilo duniyarru fu ha ɓawo man.
The WHO update on 28 September 2012 said the virus did not seem to pass easily from person to person.
Matinolji WHO je ɗon larti ha 28 Septambre 2012 mbi'i viriis ndu bana woway sallugo diga neɗɗo ha neɗɗo.
However, on 12 May 2013, a case of human-to-human transmission in France was confirmed by the French Ministry of Social Affairs and Health.
Amma, ha 12 Me 2013, wodi nyau man je salli diga neɗɗo ha neɗɗo wangi ha Faraansa e Ardudo ko Larni Kujeji Ummatore be Jam Ɓaandudu lesdi Faraansa on matini.
In addition, cases of human-to-human transmission were reported by the Ministry of Health in Tunisia.
Ha ɓesdugo, nyauɓe je sallinol neɗɗo ha neɗɗo matinama gal Aduɗo jam ɓaandu ha Tunisiya.
Two confirmed cases involved people who seemed to have caught the disease from their late father, who became ill after a visit to Qatar and Saudi Arabia.
Nyauɓe ɗiɗi je ɗon aandi mari nyau larni yimɓe je nangi nyau ha baabirawo maɓɓe je maynama, je nyawi ha ɓawo ngilli ha Qatar be Saudi Arabiya.
Despite this, it appears the virus had trouble spreading from human to human, as most individuals who are infected do not transmit the virus.
Ngam ndu, lati bana viriis man mari larula sallugo diga neɗɗo ha neɗɗo, ngam ɓurna yimɓe je mari nyau sallinatta viriis.
The final name for the virus is Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV).
Ragare inde viriis nyau koronaviriis Cakkare Funaange je ɗon hokka saɗirma nder pofɗe (MERS-CoV).

The only U.S. cases (both survived) were recorded in May 2014.In May 2015, an outbreak of MERS-CoV occurred in the Republic of Korea, when a man who had traveled to the Middle East, visited four hospitals in the Seoul area to treat his illness.

Nyauɓe Lesɗi America (ɗiɗi fu nyamɓitti) wangi ha Me 2014. Ha Me 2015, wodi nyau feere wangi ha Republic of Korea, to goɗɗo feere je waɗi jaahangal he Cakkare Funaange, ngilli cuuɗi lekki nay ha wakkere Seoul ngam hurgugo nyau mako.
This caused one of the largest outbreaks of MERS-CoV outside the Middle East.
Ndu wartiri gooto cakka nyau MERS-CoV je ɓuri yajjugo ha yaasi Cakkare Funaange
As of December 2019, 2,468 cases of MERS-CoV infection had been confirmed by laboratory tests, 851 of which were fatal, a mortality rate of approximately 34.5%.
Ha Desambre 2019, nyauɓe MERS-CoV 2 468 ɗon aandi bana ni gal lartolji suudu lartol, 851 ha kunde maɓɓe maynama, limtol mayde ɓadi 34.5%.
In December 2019, a pneumonia outbreak was reported in Wuhan, China.
Ha Desambre 2019, wangol pneumonia matinama ha Wuhan, Cayna.

On 31 December 2019, the outbreak was traced to a novel strain of coronavirus, which was given the interim name 2019-nCoV by the World Health Organization (WHO), later renamed SARS-CoV-2 by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses.
Ha 31 Desambre 2019, nyau wangi bana asngol koronaviriis keese, je ɓe hokki mo inde 2019-n-CoV tawon gal Geeɓe Duniyaru do Jam Ɓaandu.

Some researchers have suggested the Huanan Seafood Wholesale Market may not be the original source of viral transmission to humans.As of 17 April 2020, there have been at least 153,822 confirmed deaths and more than 2,240,191 confirmed cases in the coronavirus pneumonia pandemic.

Teffoɓe feere tammi yo'o Huanan Seafood Market footi na kanjuum on woni ɓundu sallinol viriis ndu ha neɗɗo. Ha 17 Aviiril 2020, yimɓe pettum man 153 822 maynama be 2 240 191 nangi nyau pneumonia koronaviriis je ɗon aandi.
The Wuhan strain has been identified as a new strain of Betacoronavirus from group 2B with approximately 70% genetic similarity to the SARS-CoV.
Asngol Wuhan ɗon maandi no bana Betakoronaviriis ha nder geeɓe 2B be ɓadi 70% naandu gene SARS-CoV.
The virus has a 96% similarity to a bat coronavirus, so it is widely suspected to originate from bats as well.
Viriis ndu ɗon naandi be 96% be koronaviriis bilwili feere, nden kadi yimɓe jur ɗon tammi wangi gal bilwili.
The pandemic has resulted in travel restrictions and nationwide lockdowns in several countries.
Nyau duniyaru ndu wangini haɗɗolji jaahangal be je wurtugo ha nder lesɗe fu.
Coronaviruses have been recognized as causing pathological conditions in veterinary medicine since the 1930s.
koronaviriis maandotto bana wurtinugo maandolji ha nder jam ɓaandu daabaji diga 1930.
Except for avian infectious bronchitis, the major related diseases have mainly an intestinal location.
Sna je bronchitis cooli je ɗon raɓɓa, ɓurna nyauji man ɗon wondi ha nder wakkere teeteki.
Coronaviruses primarily infect the upper respiratory and gastrointestinal tract of mammals and birds.
Koronaviriisji ɗon raɓɓa lawol pofɗe je do be gastrointestinal daabaji be cooli.
They also cause a range of diseases in farm animals and domesticated pets, some of which can be serious and are a threat to the farming industry.
Fahin bo'o ɓe ɗon wangina nyauji feere ha daabaji je daabaji saare, feere'en bo'o footi wona nyaɗum e lati sababu ha wakkere durugo.
In chickens, the infectious bronchitis virus (IBV), a coronavirus, targets not only the respiratory tract but also the urogenital tract.
Ha goortoɗe, viriis bronchitis je ɗɓon raɓɓa (IBV), wodi koronaviriis feere, larnay lawol pofɗe tan amma lawol siile.
The virus can spread to different organs throughout the chicken.
Viriis ndu footi sankitta ha nder kujeji ɓaandu feere fu ha goortoɗe.

Economically significant coronaviruses of farm animals include porcine coronavirus (transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus, TGE) and bovine coronavirus, which both result in diarrhea in young animals.
Koronaviriis je ɓurna fu larni daabaji saare bana koronaviriis gaduji (koronaviriis gastroenteritis je ɗon raɓɓe, TGE) be koronaviriis na'i, be sappinol fu be caarol ha ɓikkon daabaji.

Feline coronavirus: two forms, feline enteric coronavirus is a pathogen of minor clinical significance, but spontaneous mutation of this virus can result in feline infectious peritonitis (FIP), a disease associated with high mortality.
Koronaviriis paturu: irin ɗiɗi, koronaviriis paturu ɗon raɓɓa goɗɗo amma nyaɗay masin, amma sanjol laugel viriis ndu footi lata nyau paturu peritonitis (FIP), nyau je ɗon mbara yimbe jur.

Similarly, there are two types of coronavirus that infect ferrets: Ferret enteric coronavirus causes a gastrointestinal syndrome known as epizootic catarrhal enteritis (ECE), and a more lethal systemic version of the virus (like FIP in cats) known as ferret systemic coronavirus (FSC).

Fahin bo'o, wodi irin koronaviriisji ɗiɗi je ɗon raɓɓa, jiire: koronaviriis enteric jiire ɗon hokka nyau reedu je ɗon aandi bana ndamba daabaji enteritis (ECE), be wangol viriis man keese je ɓuri nyaɗugo (bana FIP ha paatuji je ɗon aandi bana koronnaviriis systemic ferret (FSC).
There are two types of canine coronavirus (CCoV), one that causes mild gastrointestinal disease and one that has been found to cause respiratory disease.
Wodi irin koronaviriis paatuji ɗiɗi (CCoV), gooto je ɗon hokka nyau reedu e je ɗon tawi bana je hokkata nyau pofɗe.
Mouse hepatitis virus (MHV) is a coronavirus that causes an epidemic murine illness with high mortality, especially among colonies of laboratory mice.
Viriis henre Doomdu (MHV) woni koronaviriis je ɗon hokka nyau murine be limtol mayde, ɓurna fu ha cakka doombi suddu lartol
Sialodacryoadenitis virus (SDAV) is highly infectious coronavirus of laboratory rats, which can be transmitted between individuals by direct contact and indirectly by aerosol.
Viriis Sialodacryoadenitis (SDAV) woni coronaviris je ɗon nyaɗi masin ha doomruweela suudu lartol je footi yimɓe sallina ha kunde maɓɓe gal ngidol mala gal hendu.
Some strains of MHV cause a progressive demyelinating encephalitis in mice which has been used as a murine model for multiple sclerosis.
Asli MHV feere ɗon hokka demyelinating encephalitis je ɗon yahida ha doombi je hoccama bana irin murine ha sclerosis jur.
Significant research efforts have been focused on elucidating the viral pathogenesis of these animal coronaviruses, especially by virologists interested in veterinary and zoonotic diseases.
Dabare teffol kanduɗum wondi do laɓɓinugo fuɗɗam pathogenesis viriis koronaviriis irin daabaji ndu, ɓurna fu gal jaanginooɓe viriisji je yardi ekkitol nyauji dabaji.
Porcine coronavirus (transmissible gastroenteritis coronavirus of pigs, TGEV).
Koronaviisus gaduji (koronaviriis reedu gaduji, TGEV).
Bovine coronavirus (BCV), responsible for severe profuse enteritis in of young calves.
Koronaviriis na'i (BCV), je ɗon hokka nyau teeteki ha ɓikkon na'i.
Feline coronavirus (FCoV) causes mild enteritis in cats as well as severe Feline infectious peritonitis (other variants of the same virus).
Koronaviriis paaturu (FCoV) ɗon hokka nyau teeteki seeɗa ha paatuji be nyau reedu Paatuji je ɗon nyaɗi (irin viriis man je feere).
the two types of canine coronavirus (CCoV) (one causing enteritis, the other found in respiratory diseases).
irin koronviriis paatuji je ɗon ɗiɗi ndu (CCoV) (gooto ɗon raɓɓa teeteki, feere tawama ha nder nyau pofɗe).
Turkey coronavirus (TCV) causes enteritis in turkeys.
Koronaviriis paula (TCV) ɗon raɓɓa teeteki paulaji.
Ferret enteric coronavirus causes epizootic catarrhal enteritis in ferrets.
Koronaviriis Jiire ɗon raɓɓa jirre be ndamba nder teeteki.
Ferret systemic coronavirus causes FIP-like systemic syndrome in ferrets.
Koronaviriis systemic Jiire ɗon hokka irin nyau systemic ha jiire.
Rabbit enteric coronavirus causes acute gastrointestinal disease and diarrhea in young European rabbits.
Koronaviriis systemic boojel ɗon memma reedu be teeteki be caarol ha ɓikkon boojelji Erop.
Porcine epidemic diarrhea virus (PED or PEDV), has emerged around the world.
Viriis nyau caarol gaduji (PED mala PEDV), waangi ha nder duniyaru.
b'Coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) is an infectious disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
Nyau koronaviriis b' 2019 (COVID-19) lati nyau je ɗon raɓɓa be saɗirma nder pofɗe je wangi gal koronaviiris 2 (SARS-CoV-2).
Common symptoms include fever, cough, and shortness of breath.
Mandolji je ɓurna larni wullol ɓaandu, sondaru, be pofɗe bana daran.
Other symptoms may include fatigue, muscle pain, diarrhea, sore throat, loss of smell, and abdominal pain.
